As part of his/her responsibility in hazard mitigation, the Emergency Management Coordinator shall supervise the development of an emergency management plan for the city, and shall recommend that plan for adoption by the city council, along with any and all mutual aid plans and agreements which are deemed essential for the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence, or reduce the impact, of such hazards if a disaster did occur. The powers of the Emergency Management Coordinator shall include the authority to declare a state of disaster in the absence of the statutorily designated individuals. The duties of the Emergency Management Coordinator shall also include the causing of a survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during a disaster, as well as a continuing study of the need for amendments and improvements in the emergency management plan. 
(Code 1992, § 1.702; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-21. - County emergency management council; joint emergency management plan. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the county judge of the County of Gillespie and the mayors of other cities in said county in the formation of an emergency management council for the county and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of a joint emergency management plan and in the appointment of a joint emergency management coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency management, insofar as said program may affect the city. 
(Code 1992, § 1.703)  
Sec. 11-22. - Duties and responsibility of Emergency Management Coordinator. 
The duties and responsibilities of the Emergency Management Coordinator or his or her designee shall include the following, all subject to the statutorily required action of the Emergency Management Director: 
(1)  The direction and control of the actual disaster operations of the emergency management organization, as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(2)  The determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(3)  The maintenance of necessary liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional, federal, or other emergency management organizations. 
(4)  The marshaling, after declaration of a disaster as provided for above, of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(5)  The coordination of the issuance of all necessary proclamations as to the existence of a disaster and the immediate operational effectiveness of the city emergency management plan. 
(6)  The coordination of the issuance of reasonable rules, regulations or directives which are necessary for the protection of life and property in the city. Such rules and regulations shall be filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(7)  The supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which the city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(8)  The supervision of, and final authorization for, the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving management within the city. 
(9)  The authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(Code 1992, § 1.704; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-23. - Emergency management organization. 
The operational emergency management organization of the city shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated in the emergency management plan, as well as all organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. Such plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate divisions and functions, assign tasks, duties and powers, and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this article. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management and the federal government. 
(Code 1992, § 1.705; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-24. - Liability. 
This article is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety, and neither the city, the agents and representatives of the city, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license or privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack shall, together with his/her successors in interest, if any, be not civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission, or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Code 1992, § 1.706)  
Sec. 11-25. - Expenditure of city funds; contractual commitment of city. 
Except in accordance with the adopted fiscal policies of the city and any existing authority of the City Manager, no person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this article, without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council. 
(Code 1992, § 1.707; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-26. - Misuse of warning signals. 
Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning signal, or the termination of a warning, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalties imposed by this article. 
(Code 1992, § 1.708)  
Sec. 11-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, repealed § 11-27, which pertained to oath or affirmation required and derived from Code of 1992, § 1.710.  
Sec. 11-28. - Interference with enforcement of section; unauthorized display of credentials; penalties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. Convictions for violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable in accordance with the general penalty found in section 1-6 of this Code. 
(Code 1992, § 1.711)  
Secs. 11-29—11-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES 
 
Sec. 11-60. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Ambulance. Any vehicle used, designed or redesigned for the transport of a patient, whether in emergency or transfer service. 
Base station physician. A physician licensed to practice medicine in the State of Texas, certified by the medical director, knowledgeable in the pre-hospital emergency medical protocols, EMS radio procedure and the general operating policies of the ambulance system, and a person from whom ambulance personnel may take medical direction by radio or other remote communications device. 
City. The City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
Emergency Medical (EMS) Administrator. Shall be the person who is responsible for administration in the emergency medical functions of the department. Such position shall be supervised by the Fire Chief. 
Emergency medical service personnel. Individuals who are qualified as ECA, basic, intermediate or paramedic emergency medical technicians under the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
EMS control center or control center. The facility designated as the central communications center from which all ambulances operating in the service area shall be dispatched and controlled. 
EMS inter-local agreement ("inter-local agreement"). That contract between the city and the County of Gillespie or other governmental or otherwise authorized entities with respect to the provision of EMS services by the city to such other entities. 
First responder. Any person, fire department vehicle, police vehicle or other vehicle not normally used for purposes of patient transport, but which vehicle and on-board personnel are capable of providing first responder services in medical emergencies. 
Helicopter rescue unit. Any rotary wing aircraft providing basic or advanced life support services and patient transportation originating from the scene of emergency incidents which occur within the service area. 
Medical audit. An official inquiry into the circumstances involving an ambulance run or request for ambulance service, conducted by the medical director or a licensed physician designated by the medical director. 
Medical control. Direction given ambulance personnel by a base station physician as required by applicable medical protocols promulgated by the medical director, and by the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
Medical director. The licensed physician appointed by the city council of the City of Fredericksburg to promulgate and update the system standard of care and to perform medical audits and otherwise monitor system performance. 
Medical protocol. Any diagnosis-specific or problem-oriented written statement of standard procedure, or algorithm, promulgated by the medical director as the normal standard of pre-hospital care for a given clinical condition. 
Mutual aid agreement. A written agreement between one or more entities whereby the signing parties agree to provide backup ambulance or other emergency medical or rescue service to one another under conditions and pursuant to terms specified in the agreement. 
Patient. Any person being transported in a reclining position from or to a health care facility from any point within the service area. 
Person. Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, governmental entity or other group or combination acting as a unit. 
Response time. The actual elapsed time between receipt of notification at the EMS control center that an ambulance is needed and the actual arrival of an ambulance, as more particularly defined in the inter-local agreement. 
Service area. That geographic area which is contained within the limits of the County of Gillespie, Texas when an interlocal agreement is in place between the City of Fredericksburg and the Commissioners Court of the County of Gillespie. 
Special event. Any public event located within the service area, for which standby ambulance service is arranged in advance, and for which an ambulance (or ambulances) are hired by the sponsor of the event or other interested party. 
System standard of care. The combined compilation of all priority-dispatching protocols, pre-arrival instruction protocols, medical protocols (i.e., first responders and ambulances), standards for certification of pre-hospital care personnel (i.e., telephone call-takers, first responders, ambulance personnel and on-line medical control physicians), as well as standards governing requirements for on-board medical equipment and supplies, and licensure of ambulance services and first responder agencies. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.502, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-61. - Creation of ambulance service. 
(a)  There is hereby created an ambulance service, emergency and transfer, for the citizens of the service area, which service shall be operated within the Fire EMS department of the city. 
(b)  The ambulance service shall be available to the citizens and those located within the city, in accordance with the terms of this article, and to the citizens of Gillespie County and those located therein, pursuant to the terms of the Inter-local Agreement (or such other and subsequent agreement that may be entered into by the city and such other parties, as approved by the city council and the governing body of such other jurisdictions). 
(c)  The business of providing ambulance service, both emergency and transfer, is declared to be a business affected by the public interest, and no person, firm or organization shall operate said business (or part thereof) within the service area, except for transfer or service used in the manner set out in section 11-67(a)(4)d. of this article. 
(d)  The ambulance service equipment held by the city shall be utilized as an ambulance service for persons requesting or utilizing such service, which shall be subject to the further provisions of this article, and such ambulance service shall be under the immediate supervision of the Fire Chief of the city, and such equipment shall be maintained at locations under the direction of such Fire Chief, subject to the approval of the city manager of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.503, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-62. - Medical director. 
(a)  City council to appoint. The city council of the City of Fredericksburg shall appoint a licensed physician as Medical Director of the emergency medical service. The medical director shall serve at the pleasure of the city council of the City of Fredericksburg. 
(b)  Appointing successors. In the event of the resignation, removal, death or disability of the medical director, a successor medical director shall be appointed by the city council of the City of Fredericksburg. The medical director shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To recommend to the city EMS Administrator medically appropriate response time standards and any necessary revisions; 
(2)  To approve the establishment and updating of the system standard of care, including without limitation medical standards for ambulance, transfer and first responder vehicles and on-board equipment; 
(3)  To approve the medical protocols and standing orders for ambulance and first responder services and periodically revise same; 
(4)  To approve the control center protocols and periodically revise same; 
(5)  To supervise medical audits and develop standard procedures for the conduct of such audits; 
(6)  To approve both written and practical tests for the certification and licensing of emergency medical services personnel, including ambulance personnel, first responders and EMS control center personnel; 
(7)  To monitor response time performance and to review reports, as necessary and furnish a report to the EMS advisory board; in this regard, the city shall furnish such, statistical information regarding response time performance as may be requested by the medical director; 
(8)  To authorize the issuance, restriction, suspension, denial, revocation and renewal by the city of emergency medical service personnel, first responders and EMS control center personnel; all subject to published procedures as may be developed by the medical director and the EMS advisory board and approved by the city council; 
(9)  To supervise periodic intensive reviews of the systems, performance relative to specific clinical types and to revise medical protocols and such other standards of the system as may be appropriate in the light of the findings; 
(10)  To conduct medical audits of individual cases as requested by the EMS advisory board, by any elected official of the city or by any licensed physician regarding a patient of such physician; 
(11)  To approve 911 protocols within the service area for "medical priority dispatch" (including pre-arrival instructions, priority code classifications and whether or not to dispatch a first responder); 
(12)  To review, as needed, a performance report to the EMS advisory board; and to present annually an oral report to the EMS advisory board concerning the state of clinical and response time performance of the ambulance system; 
(13)  To approve standards governing the operation of helicopter rescue units, including standards defining the circumstances under which such units may be dispatched to emergency scenes; and 
(14)  To conduct monthly continuing education classes/meetings with all emergency medical service personnel. 
(c)  Medical Director assistance. To the extent practical, the city, through the Fire/EMS department or other city personnel, will provide the following administrative assistance to the Medical Director. Such personnel will be designated by the Fire Chief and will be subject to medical or clinical oversight by the Medical Director in the performance of such duties; but the city personnel nevertheless will be under the ultimate supervision of the city; as employer. The typical duties of the assisting city personnel may include (but are not necessarily restricted to) the following: 
(1)  Assist in establishing ambulance and equipment standards for ambulance and first responder vehicles. 
(2)  Assist in economic impact study(ies) for new or additional equipment proposed by the medical director. 
(3)  Assist in development of control center standards and protocols. 
(4)  Administer tests for certification, licensing and permitting. 
(5)  Conduct inspections of ambulances, vehicles and equipment. 
(6)  Monitor response time performance and provide, as needed, reports to medical director and EMS advisory board. 
(7)  Assist with licensing, permitting and certificate issuance, restriction, suspension, denial, revocation and removal. 
(8)  Accumulate monthly performance data for clinical and response time performance. 
(9)  Interface with Medicare and the state as necessary. 
(10)  Handle citizen complaints. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.504, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-63. - EMS Administrator. 
(a)  The EMS Coordinator shall advise the Fire Chief with regard to the following: 
(1)  Evaluation of the response time performance and training and certification programs for city emergency medical service personnel, and such other aspects of the EMS ambulance system as may be directed by the Fire Chief. 
(2)  Advise the Fire Chief of the status of the entire emergency medical services system (i.e., county-wide and not limited to the city corporate limits), including first responder programs, public CPR, emergency management and other programs, etc., and assist in the implementation of same. 
(3)  Advise the Fire Chief from time to time as to any recommended changes in equipment needs or estimated response times. 
(4)  Advise and make recommendations to the Fire Chief with respect to resolution of issues and as to protocols, licensing and related or unrelated EMS issues. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.505, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-64. - Licenses, etc. 
Upon authorization by the Medical Director, the city, acting through its city manager or city clerk or other employee of the city designated by the city manager, shall be responsible for the actual issuance, restriction, suspension, revocation and renewal of all licenses, permits and certificates under this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.506, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-65. - Fees for service. 
(a)  Any person who utilizes the ambulance service of the city, whether such person requested the same or not, shall pay for such services the amounts specified in the schedule of fees set out in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  The fees and charges set forth and/or established herein may be changed and amended from time to time by resolution of the city council of the City of Fredericksburg and such fees and charges (and any changes or amendments) shall be set forth in and made a part of the City of Fredericksburg Fee Schedule. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.507, 9-25-2000)  
Sec. 11-66. - Failure to pay for services. 
(a)  Any person who utilizes the ambulance service of the city and who fails to pay for said service within 60 days after a statement of costs for such service has been mailed to the address of the user (or parent, in the event a minor is the user), which address for the purpose of this section will be the address which is supplied to the operator of the ambulance or which is obtained from the hospital where such person is delivered, shall be in violation of this article. 
(b)  It shall be prima facie evidence that the person utilizing such service did so with the intent to defraud upon (1) a showing that such person was notified in writing of the indebtedness for such service, which notice in writing shall be by certified or registered mail to the address as is set forth in subsection (a) hereof or by personal service of a peace officer of the city and (2) failure of such person to pay for such indebtedness within ten days after receipt of the notice. A copy of the caption of this section shall accompany the notice forwarded to the user of such services by certified or registered mail. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.508, 9-25-2000)  
Sec. 11-67. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To knowingly use or cause to be used any ambulance service other than that of the city, except those services as described in subsection (a)(4) of this section. 
(2)  For any purpose to provide ambulance service within the service area, other than by the City of Fredericksburg; or to provide helicopter rescue services, or specialized mobile intensive care services except in accordance with regulations governing the delivery of such services promulgated by the Fire Chief or this jurisdiction for the operation of such units; or to provide first responder services without approval of the Medical Director. 
(3)  To negligently or knowingly give false information to induce dispatch of an ambulance or helicopter rescue unit. 
(4)  It shall be a defense to any alleged violation of this section that the ambulance, first responder or transfer vehicle or service is being used solely in any of the following manners: 
a.  A privately owned vehicle not ordinarily used in the business of transporting a patient. 
b.  A vehicle rendering service as an ambulance in the event of a major catastrophe or extreme system overload when such condition is declared by the city manager, or by the director of emergency services of the city, or by the mayor of the city. 
c.  Any ambulance owned or operated by the federal government or any agency thereof or state government or any political subdivision thereof. 
d.  Any transport to a location within the service area, which transport originated from outside the service area. 
e.  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location within the service area and transported to a location beyond the service area, provided said ambulance or ambulance service initially transported said patient into the service area and is making the return trip. 
f.  Mutual aid calls when rendered pursuant to a mutual aid agreement executed by the city. 
g.  Special events coverage, so long as such service is provided without charge by an emergency medical services volunteer provider, as defined in the V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.003. 
h.  Wheelchair transportation services. 
i.  Medical transports by helicopter where such transports originate outside the service area or at a hospital location within the service area. 
j.  A person in favor of which the city council of the City of Fredericksburg has issued a certificate of public convenience and necessity, permitting the provision of ambulance service by such person within the service area as being necessary for the benefit and general welfare of the city and citizens. 
k.  Any transfer (non-emergency) to a location more than 90 miles outside the service area, if approved by the Emergency Services Director of the city or his designated representative. 
(b)  Violations of this section are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be prohibited and abated in actions at law or in equity. 
(c)  It shall not be necessary for the charging complaint to negate any exception contained in this section concerning any prohibited act, but any such exception made in this section may be urged as a defense by any person charged by such complaint. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.509, 9-25-2000; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-68. - Penalties. 
The following provisions for application of penalties violation of this article shall apply: 
(1)  Any person convicted of violating the provisions hereof shall be fined in accordance with section 1-6 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fredericksburg. This does not serve to limit any other remedies available in law or equity. 
(2)  Each day that any violation of this article is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.510, 9-25-2000)  
Sec. 11-69. - Traffic laws exemption. 
When the driver of an ambulance has reasonable grounds to believe that an emergency exists, as determined by the EMS control center or a medic in charge of a case, the driver of the ambulance may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the otherwise applicable provisions of law, ordinance or regulation; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits permitted by law, ordinance or regulation; provided, however, that life and property are not endangered thereby; and 
(4)  Disregard laws, ordinances and regulations governing directions or movements or turning in specific directions; provided, however, (1) that any exemption herein granted shall apply only when such ambulance is operating with siren and emergency lights in operating, and when such audible and visual signals meet the requirements of law, ordinance or regulation; and (2) that the foregoing provisions shall not operate to relieve the driver of any ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. No. 10-013a, § 6.511, 9-25-2000)  
Secs. 11-70—11-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - NATIONAL INCIDENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (NIMS) 
 
Sec. 11-101. - Adoption; background. 
(a)  Adoption. The city council adopts the National Incident Management System (NIMS), as required by HSPD-5, as the standard for incident management by the city. The NIMS, dated March 1, 2004, contains a practice model for the accomplishment of the significant responsibilities associated with prevention, preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation of all major and national hazard situations. 
(b)  Background. On February 28, 2003, the President issued Homeland Security Presidential Directive (HSPD)-5 that directed the Department of Homeland Security, in cooperation with representatives of federal, state, and local governments, to develop a National Incident Management System (NIMS) to provide a consistent approach to the effective management of situations involving natural disasters, manmade disasters or terrorism. The final NIMS was released on March 1, 2004. The HSPD-5 requires that state and local governments adopt the NIMS by fiscal year 2005 as a pre-condition to the receipt of federal grants, contracts and activities related to the management and preparedness for certain disaster and hazard situations. 
(Ord. No. 15-007, art. IV, § 11-101, 7-18-2005)  
Secs. 11-102—110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - EMERGENCY SERVICES COST RECOVERY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 24-022, adopted Oct. 20, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 11-102—11-104. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as §§ 11-111—11-113. 
 
Sec. 11-111. - Fee collection authorized. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of a structure, vehicle, or property to which the Fire/EMS Department or other department of the City of Fredericksburg (the "City") provides fire suppression, emergency management services, vehicle extrication, hazardous material mitigation, or other fire department services, (collectively referred to in this article as "Emergency Response Services") or any person or entity causing the need for the City's Fire/EMS services to respond and/or provide any emergency response service (the "Responsible Party") shall pay the cost of such service, which shall include both the base response fees (which may be imposed by other provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fredericksburg) and the Cost Recovery Fees. Cost Recovery Fees are set forth in the Appendix A of this Code of Ordinances and are hereby found to not exceed the City's actual expense in providing such emergency response services. The fees enacted herein apply to any Emergency Response Services rendered by the City to whatever property or person, whether within the City of Fredericksburg, Gillespie County or elsewhere, if requested by any other person or entity, or if supplied by the City pursuant to any interlocal cooperation agreement. 
(b)  Within 30 days of the date of providing Emergency Response Services, the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall submit an invoice for all costs, fees, charges and expenses related to the provisions of such services to the owner, occupant or other responsible party or their designated agent, representatives and insurance companies. All such bills are to be paid within 60 days of the receipt thereof. 
(c)  In addition to the cost of service described in subsection (a) above, any bills, fines or penalties, including but not limited to clean up costs, fees or expenses, that are incurred by the City or any State or Federal agencies and which are related to the same situation or occurrence shall be charged and billed separately and due as provided in subsection (b) above. 
(d)  The fees provided for herein are in addition to other fees imposed by the City in any other ordinance, and specifically are in addition to ambulance and other fees charged by the Emergency Medical Services Department of the City. 
(Ord. No. 24-022, 10-20-2014; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 11-112. - Cost recovery fee schedule. 
The cost recovery fees will be collected in the amounts set forth in Appendix A, Emergency Services Cost Recovery Fees of this code. 
(Ord. No. 24-022, 10-20-2014)  
Sec. 11-113. - Enforcement. 
The City may enforce the provisions of this article by civil actions in a court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of any amounts due hereunder plus attorney fees, costs and expenses and to obtain any other relief that may be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 24-022, 10-20-2014)  
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 14-1—14-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - UNSIGHTLY OR INSANITARY ACCUMULATIONS - PUBLIC NUISANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of home-rule municipalities concerning sanitation and health, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.081; regulation of nuisances by home-rule municipality, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.042; municipal power concerning weeds and other unsanitary matter, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.004; assessment of expenses and lien for abatement by municipality, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.007. 
 
Sec. 14-19. - Public nuisance declared. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, or entity who shall own or occupy any property in the city to allow stagnant water, weeds, brush, vegetation, junk, refuse, rubbish, carrion, or any other unsightly, unwholesome or objectionable or unsanitary matter to be kept, accumulate or grow on property owned or occupied by such person or entity. Violation hereof is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity who shall own or occupy any property in the City to use or allow the use of a vehicle, boat, trailer, recreational vehicle, container, part of a vehicle or trailer or other vehicle attachment for the storage of junk, trash and/or debris or for housekeeping, living or sleeping quarters not normally associated with the intended use of the said item. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the same was used for the collection of construction debris or materials during a construction project on the property upon which the item is placed. 
(c)  For the purposes hereof, the following definitions are used: 
(1)  Weeds, brush and vegetation shall mean and include brush, vines, grasses, clippings, fallen leaves, branches, fruit and other plant material and products on or about property which accumulate or have attained such growth as to have become a fire menace, a harbor for vermin, rats, insects, animals, reptiles or any other creatures which creates, or tends to create, a menace to health, safety or the public welfare, or an unsightly or blighting influence on the neighborhood of the property. Without limiting the foregoing definition, any growing weeds exceeding 12 inches in height shall be presumed to be a nuisance. 
(2)  Junk, refuse and rubbish shall mean and include all material decayable or non-decayable, new or used, which when kept, stored or accumulated upon property creates or tends to create an unsanitary, unsightly, unsafe environment or blighting influence on the property in question or the neighborhood. Junk, refuse and rubbish shall include all manner of items or material, dead animals or parts thereof, metal, household goods and appliances, machinery, fixtures, building materials, vehicles or motors, parts and accessories of the same. The keeping, storing and accumulating of such goods or materials shall not be considered to be a violation of this nuisance ordinance if: 
a.  The same is contained entirely within a closed receptacle or container composed of durable material designated to prevent the discharge of its contents and to be inaccessible to animals, vermin or other pests and to be inaccessible to children, or 
b.  Such material is owned or kept by a junk dealer, operating a business on the subject premises, in conformity with the zoning and other ordinances of the city. Such dealers are exempt from prosecution hereunder for keeping and accumulating such items, provided that the same be kept in a manner which does not create an unhealthy or unsafe condition and that the same be screened from public view by walls, fencing or landscaping. 
(Code 1992, § 6.301; Ord. No. 24-010, 7-21-2014)  
Sec. 14-20. - Notice to remove; authority of city to remove; assessment of cost. 
Should any owner of any lot or lots within the city who shall allow stagnant water, weeds, brush, vegetation, junk, refuse, rubbish, carrion or any other unsightly, objectionable or unsanitary matter to grow or accumulate thereon, fail and/or refuse to cut down and/or remove such weeds, rubbish, junk bush or other unsightly objectionable or unsanitary matter, as the case may be, within ten days after notice to said owner to so do, which notice shall be given as provided in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.006(b) as the same may be amended from time to time, the city may do such cutting down and/or removing the same, or cause the same to be done. The city may pay therefor, and charge the expenses incurred in doing such work or having such work done or improvements made to the owner of such lot or lots or real estate. If such work is done or improvements made at the expense of the city then such expenses shall be assessed as a lien on the real estate, or lot or lots upon which such expense was incurred. The city, and the city's authorized assistants, employees, contracting agents or other representatives are hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of cutting, destroying and/or removing such weeds, brush, vegetation, junk, refuse, rubbish, carrion or the unsightly or objectionable materials in a manner consistent with this article and with the laws governing the state. The municipal court of the city shall have authority to issue all orders necessary to enforce this article. Neither the city nor its employees, agents or contractors shall be answerable in damages or otherwise for damage to property due to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 6.302)  
Sec. 14-21. - City's costs to constitute privileged lien. 
The city manager or other person authorized to act on behalf of the city shall file a statement of such expenses incurred under section 14-20 filing the amount of such expenses, the date on which said work was done or improvements made, with the county clerk of Gillespie County Texas. The city shall have a privileged lien on such lot or lots or real estate upon which said work was done or improvements made to secure the expenditures so made, in accordance with the provisions of said V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 342, which said lien shall be second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. Said lien amount shall bear ten percent interest from the date said statement was filed. It is further provided that for any such expenditures, and interest, as aforesaid, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure of said lien may be had in the name of the city. The statement of expenses so made, as aforesaid, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work or improvements. 
(Code 1992, § 6.303)  
Sec. 14-22. - Work or improvements by municipality; notice. 
The municipality in the notice of a violation under section 14-20 may inform the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, the municipality without further notice may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this section occurs within the one-year period, and the municipality has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the municipality without notice may take any action permitted herein and assess its expense as provided by section 14-21 above. 
(Code 1992, § 6.304)  
Chapter 17 - FIRE PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Home rule municipality, fire department, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 342.011. 
 
ARTICLE I. - FIRE/EMS DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Created. 
There is hereby established and maintained for the City of Fredericksburg, a Fire/EMS Department to provide fire suppression, rescue, fire prevention, public fire education and emergency medical services (see Chapter 11) to the City and other jurisdictions in accordance with any interlocal agreement approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-2. - Fire Chief. 
The City Manager shall appoint the Fire Chief who shall be responsible for the management and administration of the Fire/EMS Department. The Fire Chief shall work at the pleasure of the City Manager. The Fire/EMS Chief may appoint and employ personnel for the Fire/EMS Department as authorized in the annual budget of the City, and as approved by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
ARTICLE II. - INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Former Art. I has been renumbered as Art. II, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, as new Art. I. 
 
Sec. 17-3. - International Fire Code adopted. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, the International Fire Code recommended by the Association of International Fire Chiefs, being particularly the 2015 edition thereof, Including Appendices "B", "C", "D", "H", and "I", and all amendments and corrections thereof, existing or issued after the date of the Ordinance from which this Section is derived. The modifications thereto adopted as section 17-3 shall also apply to the revised code hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 11-0146, § 5.101, 8-20-2001; Ord. No. 17-007, § 17-1, 3-19-2007; Ord. No. 23-013, 8-5-2013; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016; Ord. No. 2019-27 , § 10, 10-7-2019) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-1 has been renumbered as § 17-3, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Sec. 17-4. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. Shall mean the Fire Chief of the City of Fredericksburg or his or her designee. 
Corporation counsel. The city attorney for the City of Fredericksburg. 
Municipality. As used in the International Fire Code adopted in this article, it shall be held to mean the City of Fredericksburg. 
(Ord. No. 11-0146, § 5.102, 8-20-2001; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-2 has been renumbered as § 17-4, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Sec. 17-5. - Modifications to the International Fire Code. 
The Fire Chief shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the Standard Fire Prevention Code adopted in this article upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his/her duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of such code, provided that the spirit of such code be observed, public safety be secured, and substantial justice be done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the Fire Chief thereon shall be entered upon his/her records and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. Reference in section 105 thereof to the board of adjustment shall refer to the Board of Adjustment of the City of Fredericksburg. 
(Code 1992, § 5.103; Ord. No. 11-0146, art. 5.100, 8-20-2001; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-3 has been renumbered as § 17-5, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Sec. 17-6. - Removal of fire department equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, under any pretext whatsoever, other than for the purpose for which they are intended in the fire department, to take or use any engine, truck, ladder, hose or other apparatus belonging to or in possession of the fire department or volunteer fire department or to break, deface or injure the same in any manner. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1992, art. 5.200; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-4 has been renumbered as § 17-6, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Sec. 17-7. - Arson reward. 
A standing reward of $250.00 is hereby established to be paid to any person furnishing evidence as a result of which any person is arrested and finally convicted of the crime of arson, committed within the corporate limits. Such reward shall be paid out of the general fund of the city. The city council shall be the sole and exclusive judge in awarding any such reward. 
(Code 1992, art. 5.300; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-5 has been renumbered as § 17-7, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Sec. 17-8. - Fire safety, automobile service stations. 
All storage tanks at automobile service stations shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission. 
(Code 1992, art. 5.600; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016) 
Editor's note— Former § 17-6 has been renumbered as § 17-8, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016.  
Secs. 17-9—17-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FIRE MARSHAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Former Art. II has been renumbered as Art. III, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, as new Art. I. 
 
Sec. 17-31. - Created. 
The office of the Fire Marshal is hereby established. The Fire Marshal or his or her designee shall perform such duties as prescribed by law and by ordinance and shall be the authority having jurisdiction in nuisance code, arson, fire prevention and/or fire code matters. 
The Fire Marshal shall have authority to investigate all fires within the City. 
(Code 1992, § 5.401; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-32. - Appointment. 
The Fire Marshal shall be appointed by the Fire Chief with the approval of the City Manager. The Fire Marshal shall report directly to and be supervised by the Fire Chief. 
(Code 1992, § 5.402; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-33. - Duty to investigate fires. 
The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether such fire was the result of carelessness or design. Such investigation shall be commenced as soon as reasonably practical. 
(Code 1992, § 5.403; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-34. - Taking of testimony, summoning witnesses, administration of oaths, etc. 
(a)  The fire marshal, when, in his/her, opinion further investigation of a fire is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him/her to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this article, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper, or document deemed pertinent thereto. The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any persons appearing as witnesses before him/her. 
(Code 1992, § 5.404)  
Sec. 17-35. - Investigations may be private; separation of witnesses. 
All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his/her discretion, be private, and persons, other than those required to be present, may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Code 1992, § 5.405)  
Sec. 17-36. - Duty when evidence indicates crime in connection with fire. 
If the fire marshal is of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with an attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with a fire investigated by him/her, he/she shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him/her, including a copy all the pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Code 1992, § 5.406)  
Sec. 17-37. - Periodic inspections of mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings. 
It shall be the duty of the fire marshal, as often as in his discretion is necessary to maintain adequate fire prevention activities, to enter upon and make or cause to be entered and made a thorough examination of all office mercantile, manufacturing and buildings to which the public has access, together with the premises belonging thereto. 
(Code 1992, § 5.407)  
Sec. 17-38. - Ordering correction or removal of defective conditions. 
Whenever the fire marshal shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, and whenever he/she shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces, or other heating appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devices or systems, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustible, inflammable and refuse materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to the firemen or occupants, he/she shall order the same to be removed or remedied and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises. If the owner or occupant deems himself/herself aggrieved by such order, he/she may, within five days, appeal to the city manager, who shall investigate the cause of the complaint and, unless by his/her authority the order is revoked, such order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant. Any person failing to comply with such order, after the expiration of such five days, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1992, § 5.408)  
Sec. 17-39. - Misconduct of witnesses summoned by fire marshal. 
Any witness who refuses to be sworn or who refuses to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of such investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation as provided in this article, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1992, § 5.409)  
Sec. 17-40. - Records of fires to be kept. 
The fire marshal shall keep in his/her office a record of all fires, together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fires and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this article. Such records shall be kept for a period of five years from the date of the fire loss. 
(Code 1992, § 5.410)  
Sec. 17-41. - Monthly reports to state fire marshal. 
At the end of each month, the fire marshal shall report to the state fire marshal all existing hazardous conditions, together with a separate report on each fire in the city during the month. 
(Code 1992, § 5.411)  
Sec. 17-42. - Right of entry. 
The fire marshal shall have the authority at all times of day or night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon him/her by the provisions of this article, to enter upon and examine any building or premises where any fire has occurred and other buildings and premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. The fire marshal shall have the right to enter any other building or premises, with or without complaint of adjacent property owners, for the purpose of examining the same for fire hazards. 
(Code 1992, § 5.412) 
Editor's note— Should entry be denied, the fire marshal may obtain entry by a search warrant issued as provided for by state law.  
Sec. 17-43. - Unsafe conditions in structures; notice for abatement; penalty for failure to comply with notice. 
(a)  Any owner or occupant of a building or other structure or premises, who shall keep or maintain the same when, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or for any cause, such structure is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger buildings, or property of others, or is especially liable to fire and which is so occupied that fire would endanger other persons or their property therein, shall be punished according to the provisions of section 1-6 of this Code. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant of any building or other structure, or premises, who shall keep or maintain the same with an improper arrangement of a stove, range, furnace, or other heating appliance of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues, and pipes with which the same may be connected so as to be dangerous in the matter of fire, or health, or safety of persons or property of others; or who shall keep or maintain any building, other structure or premise with an improper arrangement of a lighting device or system, or with a storage of explosives, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustibles, inflammable materials, refuse, or with any other condition which shall be dangerous in character to the health or property of others; or which shall be dangerous in the matter of promoting, augmenting or causing fires; or which shall create conditions dangerous to firemen or occupants of such building, structure or premises other than the maintainer thereof, shall be punished according to the provisions of section 1-6 of this Code. 
(c)  No prosecution shall be brought under paragraphs (a) and (b) of this section until the order provided for in section 17-39 be given and the party notified shall fail or refuse to comply with the same for a period of five days following the notice. 
(Code 1992, § 5.413) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority concerning substandard building, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.001; additional authority to secure substandard building, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 214.0011, 214.0015.  
Sec. 17-44. - Fire Marshal Fees and Charges. 
Fees shall be paid for permit review, plan review, inspections, and other miscellaneous fire protection services rendered by the City's Fire Marshal, as set forth in the fee schedule found in appendix A to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 28-020, § 1, 10-1-2018)  
Secs. 17-45—17-61. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - VOLUNTEERS FOR THE FIRE/EMS DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Former Art. III has been renumbered as Art. IV, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, as new Art. I. 
State Law reference— Volunteer firefighters and fire departments, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 419.071. 
 
Sec. 17-62. - Number of members. 
The volunteer fire department shall consist of not more than 45 active members and as many more as the city council by resolution may find necessary. The volunteers will be supervised by the Fire Chief of the City of Fredericksburg. 
(Code 1992, § 5.501; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-63. - Officers, election of officers. 
The officers of the volunteer fire department shall be classified into two groups: namely business officers and fire-fighting officers. The business officers shall be the president, vice-president, treasurer and secretary. The fire-fighting officers shall be the assistant chief, two captains, two lieutenants and one or more fire station officers who shall also serve as the role of Captain, and such other officers as may be necessary to carry out the work of such department. The Fire Chief shall serve as an at-large, voting member of the volunteer fire department and shall serve Ex officio for all meetings of the business and firefighting volunteers, and committees thereof, and shall offer support and assistance to all officers. All volunteer officers shall be elected by the volunteers annually on the second Thursday in December and shall take office the following January 1 for the entire calendar year. 
(Code 1992, § 5.502; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-64. - Duties of officers generally. 
It shall be the responsibility of the Fire Chief and president to see that all laws, orders, rules and regulations concerning the volunteer fire department are carried out. Additionally, the Fire Chief and president will enforce the rules and regulations made to secure discipline in the volunteer fire department. The secretary of the volunteer fire department shall keep the minutes for each meeting and be responsible for all correspondence from the fire department. The treasurer shall be responsible for all funds and accounts belonging to the volunteer fire department and shall give a report each meeting to the general membership. The treasurer will also be responsible for paying all accounts payable and keeping a set of books for each account. The Fire Chief (with assistance from the volunteers) shall see that all apparatus and equipment of the Fire/EMS Department is kept in proper order and repair. The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the city municipal budget dealing with the Fire/EMS Department and approve all expenditures from that budget. The Fire Chief shall also oversee the administrative and operational activities of the Fire/EMS Department career personnel and the volunteer fire department officers and volunteers in the delivery of fire suppression and fire prevention activities. The Fire Chief or his designee, shall be the designated Fire/EMS representative of the unified command in any large incident or disaster that involves multiple agencies or disciplines. 
(Code 1992, § 5.503; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-65. - Specific duties of the Fire Chief. 
The Fire Chief of the City of Fredericksburg shall have command over all other officers, members of the Fire/EMS department, volunteers and all persons who may be present at a fire or other emergency. In his/her absence, his or her designee, or in the absence of a designee, the next highest-ranking officer shall fill this position, generally and in the unified command system. The Fire Chief shall direct placement of the firefighting equipment, and shall take all proper measures for extinguishing the fire, protection of property, preservation of order, observance of state laws and city ordinances and regulations, respecting fires. 
(Code 1992, § 5.504; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-66. - General duties of volunteer firefighters. 
Upon an alarm, all active members of the volunteer fire department shall report to the fire station, the location of the ambulances, or may go straight to the scene as the current rules of the Fire/EMS Department allows. The volunteer firefighters shall respond in full turnout gear or issued protective gear from the station in fire department apparatus under their care, and shall work the same under the direction of the officer in command at such fire until such fire is extinguished. Those who are certified as medical personnel shall respond as required with the equipment and under the protocols established for them. Apparatus shall then be returned to its place of keeping in a ready-to-respond mode (cleaned, stocked and re-fueled). The city council shall provide facilities for Fire/EMS Department vehicles. The members of the fire department, including the volunteer firefighters and medical personnel, shall keep all such apparatus and equipment in constant readiness for use. 
(Code 1992, § 5.505; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-67. - Liability for damage. 
Neither the city council, city manager, the Fire Chief, or any member of the fire department, shall in any way be held responsible for damages occasioned to property during attempts to extinguish fires, or for the destruction thereof, or for damage done to any person, animal or vehicle coming into collision with the fire extinguishing apparatus or the vehicles driven by members of the department when proceeding to the place of a fire or to the fire station when responding to a fire call. 
(Code 1992, § 5.506; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-68. - Roping off streets, buildings, etc., during a fire. 
The fire chief, or the officer in command, shall have the right to order the placing of ropes or guards across all streets, alleys or lanes on which may be situated any building on fire, and at such other points as may be deemed expedient and necessary, and they shall prevent the entrance of all persons, except firemen, into the danger zone. If advisable, owners and occupants of and employees in adjoining buildings, endangered by the existing fire, may be admitted. 
(Code 1992, § 5.507)  
Sec. 17-69. - Right-of-way; control of traffic when proceeding to a fire. 
All movable apparatus of the Fire/EMS Department and vehicles driven by members of the department shall have paramount right-of-way through all streets, lanes, alleys, places and courts of the city when running to a fire. In order to give such apparatus and the vehicles of the members of the department the unobstructed use of the public ways, upon an alarm, all pedestrians shall get off such public ways and vehicles thereon shall be parked at the curb, or drawn up on the right next to vehicles parked at the curb and halted, or shall be driven off at the next intersection, if necessary to clear the way for the fire apparatus and accompanying vehicles. Traffic shall not be continued until all fire-fighting equipment has cleared the immediate area. 
(Code 1992, § 5.508; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-70. - Right to destroy buildings to prevent spread of fire. 
Whenever any building in the city is on fire, it shall be lawful for the chief, or acting chief, to direct such building, or adjoining buildings, erection, or fences likely to burn and communicate the fire to other buildings, to be torn down or blown up, or otherwise destroyed in order to check or extinguish the existing fire. 
(Code 1992, § 5.509; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-71. - Right of arrest. 
During the progress of a fire in the city, and for 24 hours after its extinguishment, the chief of police, or other police officers of the city, may arrest and keep in custody all persons suspected of arson, idle, disorderly or suspicious persons, and persons who hinder any firefighter in the discharge of his or her duty or resist or refuse to obey any such officer while acting in the discharge of his/her duty. 
(Code 1992, § 5.510; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-72. - Interference with fire department in fighting fires prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, not a member or members of the Fire/EMS Department, to interfere with or in any manner hinder the Fire/EMS Department or any member or employee of said fire department in the discharge of its or his/her duties as such, unless ordered to do so provided for in the previous section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, not a member or employee of said Fire/EMS department, to handle or in any way interfere with any of the apparatus belonging to or used by said Fire/EMS department whether at a fire, going to or coming from a fire, while housed at the fire station, or at any time, unless requested to do so by a member of said Fire/EMS Department. 
(Code 1992, § 5.511; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-73. - Passage of other rules and regulations. 
The Fire/EMS Department may pass such additional regulations not inconsistent with the provisions hereof, with other ordinances of the city, and with the laws of the state, which it deems necessary for its good government, and any member of the volunteer fire department who fails or refuses to comply therewith and with the provisions hereof shall forfeit his/her membership in such department. 
(Code 1992, § 5.512; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Secs. 17-74—17-94. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OUTDOOR FIRES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Former Art. IV has been renumbered as Art. V, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, as new Art. I. 
 
Sec. 17-95. - Outdoor fires regulated. 
Whenever it shall become necessary for any person to have a fire out of doors for cooking, washing, or any other purely domestic purposes, such person is hereby required to build such fire in a fire proof container of some kind, made of brick, stone, metal or other fire proof material in such manner as to prevent said fire from escaping. All other fires shall require a permit from the building official and shall be subject to such conditions as he or she may place upon such permit. All other fires shall require a permit from the fire marshal and shall be subject to such conditions as that official may place on the permit. 
(Code 1992, § 5.701)  
Sec. 17-96. - Fire prohibited on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to light or have lighted any fire in any street, alley, thoroughfare, or public property. 
(Code 1992, § 5.702)  
Sec. 17-97. - Adoption of air pollution regulations by reference. 
The city hereby adopts in its entirety the Texas Clean Air Act and Federal Pollution Act by reference insofar as each of said acts pertains to cities, towns and villages in the category in which the city falls by a population category. 
(Code 1992, § 5.703) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to abate air pollution in matter consistent with state law and rules of Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 382.113.  
Secs. 17-98—17-117. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FIREWORKS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Former Art. V has been renumbered as Art. VI, at the editor's discretion, to facilitate inclusion of Ord. No. 26-014, adopted Oct. 3, 2016, as new Art. I. 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to regulate explosives, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.001; state law does not preempt municipal authority to prohibit or regulate use of fireworks, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2154.004; regulation of fireworks and fireworks displays, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2154.001 et seq.; fireworks use, displays and regulations, 28 Tex. Admin. Code § 34.800 et seq. 
 
Sec. 17-118. - Use of fireworks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to fire, explode or cause to be exploded any firecrackers, cannon crackers, Roman candles, sky rockets, torpedoes, or other fireworks or similar noise making articles, within the corporate limits or within 5,000 feet of the city limits; provided, however, that the Fire Marshal may issue permits to civic organizations for special fireworks displays and cannon firing upon a showing that such exhibits and/or firing will not create a fire hazard or be otherwise hazardous to any property, or dangerous to any person or persons, and provided that such organization complies with the safety provisions of the fire marshal. 
(Code 1992, § 7.501; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Sec. 17-119. - Sale of fireworks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, or to have in his/her possession with the intent to give away, sell or offer for sale, or to sell within the city limits, any firecrackers, cannon crackers, Roman candles, sky rockets, torpedoes, or other combustible fireworks of any kind. 
(Code 1992, § 7.502; Ord. No. 26-014, 10-3-2016)  
Chapter 20 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipality may not enact or enforce a law making conduct covered under the state Penal Code an offense subject to criminal penalty, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 1.08; authority of municipality to define, prohibit, and enforce prohibition of nuisances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.042. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Discharge of firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm, including BB guns, in the city limits or within 5,000 feet of the city limits without first securing the permission of the chief of police or his/her deputies. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Law enforcement peace officers when acting in performance of their official duties. 
(2)  Shooting ranges which are operated by the police department or under the supervision of the park board, or which are privately operated if approved by the police department. 
(3)  The use of blank cartridges for a show or theatrical production, for signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports, or by military organizations. 
(4)  Self defense or justifiable or excusable homicide situations. 
(5)  Hunting and/or shooting on one's own property or with written permission of the owner of the property. 
(6)  Destroying predatory animal on one's own property or with written permission of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1992, art. 7.400) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to regulate firearms and explosives, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 229.001.  
Sec. 20-2. - Fishing, Lady Bird Johnson municipal park. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to take fish by means of any net, trotline, throwline or spear gun in any of the waters within the confines of Lady Bird Johnson Municipal Park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person in any one day to catch and retain, or to place on or in any device or container for holding same while he/she is fishing, any fish that is taken from the waters within the confines of said park in excess of the limits established in the regulations of the state parks and wildlife department. 
(Code 1992, art. 7.600) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority concerning public waters within corporate limits, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.092.  
Sec. 20-3. - Camping in City Parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to camp upon any City park land. 
(b)  This Section 20-3 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Camping in areas of City park land specifically set aside and clearly marked for public camping purposes; and 
(2)  Camping during special events located on City park land when specifically authorized by the Director of Parks and Recreation. 
(c)  For purposes of this Section 20-3, the term "camp" or "camping" shall be defined as: 
(1)  The parking and occupying of a recreational vehicle or camper to provide sleeping quarters for temporary human habitation; 
(2)  The erection of a tent to provide sleeping quarters for temporary human habitation; or 
(3)  The use of other materials, including but not limited to, sleeping bags, bedrolls, blankets, sheets, tarps, and cardboard, to provide sleeping quarters for temporary human habitation. 
(d)  For purposes of this Section 20-3, the term "City park land" shall be defined as: 
(1)  Cross Mountain Park; 
(2)  Elementary School Park; 
(3)  Ft. Martin Scott; 
(4)  Frantzen Park; 
(5)  Lady Bird Johnson Municipal Park; 
(6)  Marktplatz (Market Square); 
(7)  Oak Crest Park; 
(8)  Old Fair Park; 
(9)  Any City owned land specifically set aside and clearly marked for public use as a playground or organized sports field; and 
(10)  Any streets, roadways or parking areas within the boundaries of the land areas set forth above in Sections 20-3(d)(1) through 20-3(d)(9). 
(e)  Upon conviction of any violation of this Section 20-3, a person shall be subject to penalties as provided by Section 1-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 28-016, § 1, 10-1-2018)  
Sec. 20-4. - SEX OFFENDERS. 
A.  Finding and intent. The City Council finds that child sex predators, who are required to register as a sex offender under Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. ch. 62, present a threat to the health, safety and welfare of children. The City Council further finds that children lack the ability to protect themselves from sexual predators, and additional safety measures are required to prevent certain registered sex offenders from having access to children in areas where children generally feel safe. 
It is the intent of this Section 20-4 to serve the City's compelling interest to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City, by creating areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers, wherein certain registered child sex offenders are prohibited from entering, loitering, or establishing temporary or permanent residency. 
B.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Section 20-4, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, and terms not defined here shall be construed as in ordinary and common usage. 
Child safety area shall mean all improved and unimproved areas of a lot or tract of land that is used as a private or public elementary or secondary school, a day-care center or facility, a private or public playground, a private or public youth center, a public swimming pool, a video arcade facility, an amusement park, a carnival or fair, a public park, and any children's section of a public library. 
Child sex offender shall mean any person with a reportable conviction or adjudication, including an adjudication of delinquent conduct or a deferred adjudication, that, regardless of the pendency of an appeal, is a conviction for or an adjudication for or based on any of the following offenses: 
(1)  Continuous sexual abuse of a young child or children (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.02); 
(2)  Indecency with a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.11); 
(3)  Sexual assault of a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.011); 
(4)  Aggravated sexual assault of a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.021); 
(5)  Online solicitation of a minor (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 33.021); 
(6)  Sexual performance by a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.25); 
(7)  Possession or promotion of child pornography (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.26); or 
(8)  A violation of the laws of another state, federal law, laws of a foreign country, or the Uniform Code of Military Justice, if the violation contained elements substantially similar to the elements of the violations described (1) through (7) of this paragraph. 
Day-care center or facility shall mean a facility licensed by the State of Texas, which provides care, training, education, custody, treatment, or supervision of children for less than 24 hours a day. 
Loiter shall mean standing or sitting idly or without apparent purpose, whether or not in a motor vehicle. 
Minor shall mean any person under 18 years of age. 
Permanent residence shall mean a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more consecutive days. 
Person in authority shall mean the owner, a person authorized by the owner, or a person or business with apparent authority to act for the owner, including but not limited to, a manager or a property management business. 
Playground, Premises, School, Video arcade facility , and Youth center shall have the meanings assigned by V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 481.134. 
Public park shall mean: 
(1)  any land, including improvements to said land, designated as a public park or public recreation area for use by the general public, including but not limited to City parks, water parks, conservation areas, jogging trails, and hiking trails; and 
(2)  any athletic field that is owned, leased, operated, managed, or maintained by the City, including but not limited to soccer fields, baseball fields, softball fields, basketball courts, and football fields. 
Reportable conviction or adjudication shall have the meaning assigned by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. § 62.001(5). 
Temporary residence shall mean: 
(1)  a place where a person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent residence; and 
(2)  a place where a person abides, resides, or lodges for a period of four or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
C.  Sex offender entry and loitering restriction. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a child sex offender to intentionally or knowingly enter a child safety area. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for a child sex offender to intentionally or knowingly loiter within 1,000 feet of a child safety area. Under this Subsection 20-4(C), any distance measurement is made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, between the child sex offender's location and the nearest property line of the child safety area. 
(3)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this Subsection 20-4(C) if at the time of the offense, a child sex offender has entered a child safety area for such time as is necessary to attend a regular, special, or called meeting of a governmental body that is open to the public pursuant to V.T.C.A., Texas Government Code ch. 551. The defense under this Subsection 20-4(C)(3) shall only apply to those areas of the child safety area that are necessary for attendance at the meeting of a governmental body. 
(4)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this Subsection 20-4(C) if at the time of the offense, a child sex offender has entered a child safety area for such time as is necessary for the limited purpose of voting at an official polling place located within a child safety area, if the child sex offender qualifies to vote at such polling place. The defense under this Subsection 20-4(C)(4) shall only apply to those areas of the child safety area that are necessary for the limited purpose of voting. 
(5)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this Subsection 20-4(C) if at the time of the offense, a child sex offender has entered the premises of any school during the standard operating hours of the school and complied with Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 62.064. 
(6)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this Subsection 20-4(C) if at the time of the offense, a child sex offender has entered a child safety area for such time as is necessary for the limited purpose of accompanying a child under 18 years of age on the premises of the child safety area, provided said child sex offender is the parent or legal guardian of the child. 
D.  Sex offender Halloween restrictions. 
(1)  On October 31 of each year, a child sex offender shall: 
(a)  Remain at their residence of registry between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 11:59 p.m.; 
(b)  Not illuminate any exterior lights upon the premises at their residence of registry between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 11:59 p.m.; and
