(b)  An application for a permit shall be filed with the building permit department of the City of Fredericksburg and shall contain all information relevant to determine the exact nature, size, look and placement of the improvement for which a permit is sought as well as the name, address and phone number of the applicant and owners of adjacent property (the building official may require proof of ownership). The building official shall provide copies of the application to the owners of the adjacent property at least five days prior to approval. 
(c)  An application shall not be considered complete or submitted unless accompanied by an application fee of $25.00. 
(d)  Not later than 30 days after a completed application is filed, the applicant shall be notified in writing of the decision of the issuance or denial of the permit. The building official may place such reasonable conditions on such permit as will promote public safety. Improvements, except as described below, or objects in the public way as of the effective date of this article are not "grandfathered," and must be removed by order of the building official if he or she determines that the same would not have been approved under the terms of this article, or an official of the State of Texas, as applicable, if in state right of way. Canopies and posts to support the same, which are existing as of August 1, 1999, shall be permitted to remain without the necessity of obtaining a permit. Any alteration (i.e. other than ordinary maintenance) of the same shall require a permit as set out above. 
(e)  In the event of changed circumstances, such as a change in use of adjoining property, changes in streets, sidewalks or utilities, overgrowth of landscape material or other change that would render an item or improvement unsafe or blocking of access or the like, any items or improvements within the public way may be required to be removed by the building official of the City of Fredericksburg or his or her designee, and any permit concerning the same may be revoked. In the event of revocation, the permittee, or the adjoining property owner (if the placement existed at the effective date hereof) shall remove the item or improvement designated within five days of the date of the notice at his or her cost. If the same is not done, the city may remove such item and charge its cost of removal of same to the property owner, owner of the item, or the person who placed such item. Reimbursement to the city shall be made within 30 days of demand therefor. The city shall not be responsible to any party for the value of the item removed. 
(f)  Within six months following the effective date hereof, the building official, or his or her designee, shall survey the public way in the district and shall automatically permit, with no permit cost, all improvements existing as of the effective date hereof which in his or her opinion are acceptable under the terms hereof. 
(g)  In the event the building official denies the issuance of a permit to place property or improvements as described in this section, or revokes a permit, an applicant may appeal such denial to the board of adjustment of the City of Fredericksburg. Such appeal must be written and delivered to the city secretary of the City of Fredericksburg within ten days of the date of notification of the denial. The date of notification of the denial shall be deemed to be the date the applicant is personally notified of the decision of the building official or the date upon which the building official mails (certified mail) a written copy of his/her decision to the address noted upon the application. The grounds for appeal, and the standard of review to be applied by the board of adjustment is that the action of the building official was arbitrary and capricious and not based upon existing or anticipated conditions for the area for which an improvement is requested. 
(Ord. No. 10-002, art. 4.1003, 2-7-2000; Ord. No. 11-012, art. 4.1003, 6-4-2001)  
Secs. 35-25—35-51. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - NEWSRACK REGULATION 
 
Sec. 35-52. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
Abandoned newsrack means any newsrack which remains empty of publications or unserviced for 30 consecutive days. 
Business days are Mondays through Fridays, excluding any legal holidays observed by the city. 
City means the City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
Director means the city's director of development services, or his/her designated representative. 
Historical district means the area legally recognized and known as the historic overlay district defined in the zoning ordinance of the City of Fredericksburg, as the same may be amended from time to time, including all adjoining streets and alleys. 
Manned vending means the sale, display or distribution, with or without charge, of newspapers, news periodicals, news publications or other printed matter, or subscriptions thereto, using individual sellers or distributors. 
Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the unmanned vending, display and sale, or distribution with or without charge, of newspapers, news periodicals, news publications or other printed news material. 
Right-of-way means the entirety of any public street area, including the public roadway and adjacent pedestrianways. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1101, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-53. - Newsrack identification. 
Each newsrack shall have permanently affixed to it, in a location and manner that is readily visible, identification which shall include the name, address and telephone number of the distributor and/or representative of the newspaper. Identification information shall be kept current at all times. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1102, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-54. - Newsrack location. 
(a)  No newsrack shall be placed, used or maintained which in whole or in part rests upon any portion of any street or other right-of-way on which motor vehicles are lawfully permitted. 
(b)  No newsrack shall be placed, used or maintained which in whole or in part rests upon any portion of any street, sidewalk or other right-of-way, when such placement, use or maintenance; endangers the safety of persons or property; unreasonably interferes with public utility purposes, public transportation, or other governmental use; or unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or any legally parked or stopped vehicle, or the use of traffic signs or signals, police or fire call boxes, transit shelters, sidewalks, elevators, mailboxes, or other objects located at or near said location, or access to or use of delivery areas or loading zones. 
(c)  No newsrack shall be placed, used or maintained within three feet of any fire hydrant, marked pedestrian crosswalk, designated handicapped parking or handicapped ramp facility or in any location where such newsrack leaves less than five feet of clear space for pedestrian passage. 
(d)  Newsracks installed next to a property line shall be placed within 12 inches of the property line. Newsracks installed next to a curb line shall not be placed within 18 inches of the curb line. 
(e)  Newsracks shall be no taller than 43 inches in height nor wider than 20 inches in width, and 16 inches deep and may be modular units containing more than one publication. All newsracks must be constructed and installed in a safe manner and must be able to withstand strong winds. All newsracks must be maintained. 
(f)  Newsracks located in the historic district must also comply with the provisions of section 35-58 below. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1103, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-55. - Installation; maintenance. 
(a)  Newsracks permanently mounted, attached or secured in the right-of-way shall be in conformance with accepted procedures and shall utilize bolts and/or fasteners specifically designed for such purpose. 
(b)  No method of permanently mounting, attaching or securing in the right-of-way shall be used that will in any manner damage the right-of-way or create a hazard for pedestrians or obstruction to handicap accessibility. Newsracks shall not be secured to fire hydrants, call boxes, sprinkler inlets, standpipes, public signs, handrails, planters, benches, trees or light poles. 
(c)  The distributor and/or representative of any such permanently mounted, attached or secured newsrack shall be responsible for repairs of any damage to the right-of-way caused by the installation or the maintenance of the newsrack. Upon removal of any such newsrack, all bolts or fasteners shall be made flush with or completely removed from the right-of-way and the right-of-way shall be restored as nearly to its original condition as practicable. 
(d)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in good appearance and working order by its distributor and/or representative. Any newsrack not in good repair and working order shall be repaired, replaced or removed within 15 business days after written notice of such defective condition. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1104, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-56. - Seizure, removal of newsracks in violation; right to hearing. 
(a)  Any newsrack installed or maintained in violation of this chapter may be seized and removed by the director of development services, the code enforcement section or by a member of the police department of the city. Before any newsrack is seized, the distributor and/or representative shall be notified and given 15 business days in which to remedy the violation or to request a hearing to contest the removal. Notice to the distributor and/or representative shall be in writing, sent by first class mail, return receipt requested, to the address indicated on the newsrack and an additional notice tag shall be a fixed to the newsrack on the date of notice. If no identification is shown on the newsrack, only the notice tag affixed to the newsrack shall be required. Every notice shall indicate the name and address of the person to contact to contest the seizure and/or request a hearing. 
(b)  The distributor and/or representative of any newsrack alleged to be in violation of this chapter may request a hearing before the board of adjustment of the City of Fredericksburg. The hearing shall be informal, but oral and written evidence may be presented by either the distributor and/or representative or the city. Any action by the city with respect to the alleged violation shall be stayed pending the board's decision, except pursuant to subsection (d). The board shall give oral notice of the decision immediately after the hearing, and shall give written notice of the decision within five business days after the hearing. 
(c)  The above authorized persons may seize and remove a newsrack which remains in violation of this chapter: 
(1)  Fifteen consecutive business days following the notice of violation, if the distributor and/or representative has not requested a hearing before the board of adjustment; or 
(2)  Ten business days after the distributor and/or representative receives the written decision of the board of adjustment that the newsrack is in violation of this chapter. Seized newsracks shall be retained by the city for a period of at least 30 days following the seizure, and may be recovered by the distributor and/or representative at any time while in the city's possession following the payment of all fines imposed and an impoundment fee which shall be set by the director of development services of the City of Fredericksburg based on the cost to the city of the removal and storage but which shall not be less than $50.00 or other applicable fees. 
(d)  If a newsrack is installed or maintained in such a place or manner as to pose an immediate and serious danger to persons or property, anyone authorized by subsection (a) above will first make a reasonable attempt to contact the distributor and/or representative of the newsrack and request immediate relocation or removal. If the distributor and/or representative is unable to be contacted or does not respond to appropriate notification, the enforcement officer may seize such newsrack without further notice to the distributor and/or representative. Seizure and removal of a newsrack pursuant to this subsection shall take place only if it is impractical for the city to remedy the violation by moving the newsrack to another location on the street, sidewalk, or other right-of-way without mechanical assistance. If the newsrack is seized pursuant to this subsection, the enforcement officer shall attempt to notify the distributor and/or representative in writing of the seizure. 
(e)  Abandoned newsracks may be removed by any person authorized by subsection (a) above and shall be disposed of by the city if not claimed by the distributor and/or representative within 30 days after removal. The above notwithstanding, at least 15 business days before any newsrack is removed under this subsection, the distributor and/or representative shall be given written notice that such newsrack is suspected of being abandoned, and upon removal of any abandoned newsrack the enforcement officer shall notify in writing the distributor and/or representative of the removal. The distributor and/or representative may request a hearing before the board of adjustment within ten business days of the removal to contest the removal. Such newsrack shall not be removed if, before removal, the registrant informs the director of development services that the newsrack has not been abandoned and promptly stocks and maintains such newsrack in compliance with the terms of this chapter within three days of notification of the director. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1105, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-57. - Manned vending. 
(a)  No individual may engage in manned vending upon any portion of any street or other right-of-way on which motor vehicles are lawfully permitted to operate. 
(b)  No individual under the age of 16 may engage in manned vending in the right-of-way. 
(c)  Any individual engaged in manned vending upon any authorized portion of the right-of-way shall have within his/her possession an identification certificate with a current photograph of the individual vendor; the name, address, telephone number and authorized signature of the entity by whom the individual vendor is employed or authorized; and an identification number that is unique to such individual vendor. 
(d)  There shall be no limitation on or permit, license, or fee charged for manned vending except as expressly provided herein. Each individual vendor engaging in manned vending shall be deemed to be a newsrack location for purposes of insurance and indemnification as set out below, and the terms "newsrack" and "manned vendor" shall be interchangeable in such parts. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1106, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-58. - Historical district. 
(a)  Newsracks installed and maintained in the historical district shall be painted in solid colors in a shade approved by the director, and be on an acceptable industry newsrack pedestal or freestanding design and configuration. The selection of the guidelines for "acceptable" newsracks shall be determined by the director of development services. 
(b)  Newsracks located in the public right of way shall be located linearly side by side next to a building or property line as described below. Newsracks a shall be placed parallel to the street, in the following locations and with the following number limitations: 
(1)  Location 1. At 323 East Main Street, commonly known as the Auslander Restaurant area, against the north wall (facing Main Street) of the building; five spots available 
(2)  Location 2. At 225 West Main Street, commonly known as the Old German Bakery area, against the North wall (facing Main Street) of the building; five spots available 
(3)  Location 3. Against the West wall of the building located at 201 East Main Street, commonly known as the Cornerstone Market Area, along South Llano Street on the east side of the street; five spots available 
(4)  Location 4. Against the West wall of the building located at 101 East Main Street, commonly known as the Back Porch Area, along South Adams Street, on the east side of the street; five spots available 
(c)  Newsracks installed and maintained in the historic district shall each have a City of Fredericksburg registration number attached to the unit to be issued as follows: 
(1)  Within 90 days after the effective date of this article, each publication, person, or other entity desiring to keep existing newsracks, place and maintain one or more new newsracks in the historic district shall file an application with the director of development services, indicating those Locations at which it desires to have newsracks, The application shall be on a form established by said director. 
(2)  In order to be considered complete, an application must include or be accompanied by: evidence that the insurance requirements of this chapter will be met for each newsrack to be assigned to the applicant and a listing of the publications to be displayed in each newsrack. 
(d)  The director of development services shall assign locations and spots and issue registration numbers for each as follows: 
(1)  Newsracks which are existing as of January 1, 2004, and which are in compliance with the requirements of this article (other than having an approved location or registration number) or which are brought into compliance within 30 days after the effective date of this article codified in this chapter, shall be allowed to be relocated into an approved location and remain until abandoned or removed voluntarily or in accordance with this chapter. 
(2)  For each of the locations identified in subsection (b) above for which additional spots are available after the 90-day period described above, the director of development services shall assign any remaining spots. For any location for which the number of applications no not exceed the available spots, the assignment of spots shall be according to the order in which the applications were filed and deemed complete. 
(3)  For any locations for which more applications are received than there are available spots, the director shall assign the remaining spots by random drawing, which shall be open to the public. No publication shall be entitled to more than two locations within the historic district if all publications for which applications are filed cannot be accommodated. 
(4)  Publications existing at any location and spot shall be permitted to remain from year to year. In the event the number of publications requesting space becomes too many to be reasonably accommodated, the director may decrease the number of spots allocated to one per publication or conduct a drawing for all the spots. In which case procedure for assigning locations shall be repeated annually, but only with respect to those locations for which competing applications have been filed. The drawing shall be conducted on the first business day of February of each year. The director of development services shall establish submittal and deadline rules as may be necessary to accomplish the purposes of this chapter. 
(5)  Newsracks located on private property shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1107, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-59. - Insurance. 
Each distributor and/or representative or other person or entity responsible for the newsracks or manned vending shall maintain in force public liability and property damage insurance, naming the city as an additional insured, in an amount not less than $100,000.00 minimum liability combined single limit (bodily injury and property damage) per person and per occurrence. The insurance shall include a statement by the insurance carrier that such carrier will give the director of development services of the City of Fredericksburg 30 days' notice before canceling such insurance. Failure to carry the required insurance at all times shall, pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, authorize the removal of the relevant newsracks by any authorized enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1108, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-60. - Indemnification of city. 
Any distributor and/or representative installing or maintaining a newsrack under this chapter agrees, by the placement of the newsrack, to indemnify and to hold harmless the city and its representatives from all claims, demands and liability arising out of or encountered in connection with the installation or maintenance by or on behalf on such distributor and/or representative or other responsible person or entity of any newsrack on public property, except for only such injury or harm as may be caused solely by the negligence of the city or its authorized representatives. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1109, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-61. - General administration. 
The director of development services of the City of Fredericksburg is hereby authorized to adopt administrative rules and regulations for implementation and administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1110, 3-1-2004)  
Sec. 35-62. - Compliance required. 
All newsracks located within the city shall be brought into compliance with the terms of this article within six months following the date of its passage by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 14-004, § 4.1111, 3-1-2004)  
Secs. 35-63—35-82. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIRS OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 35-83. - Definitions. 
Whenever in this article the following terms or pronouns in place of them are used, the intent and meaning shall be interpreted as follows: 
City. City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
Street. In addition to the definition set out in section 1-3 of this Code, street shall mean, for the purposes of this article, sidewalks, driveways and curbcuts. 
Superintendent. Street superintendent for the City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
(Code 1992, § 3.801)  
Sec. 35-84. - Superintendent to be supervisor of all paving, excavations, etc. 
The superintendent is hereby charged with the general supervision of all excavations, cuts, repairs, or paving work done in the city. 
(Code 1992, § 3.802)  
Sec. 35-85. - Work to satisfy superintendent. 
All work done on the city streets shall be done to the satisfaction of the superintendent, and in accordance with the specifications set out in chapter 5, article XII. 
(Code 1992, § 3.803)  
Sec. 35-86. - Laws and regulations applicable. 
Any person seeking a permit to work on the city streets or sidewalks shall make himself/herself familiar with, and at all times shall observe and comply with all federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations which in any manner affect the conduct of the work. 
(Code 1992, § 3.804)  
Sec. 35-87. - Permits. 
(a)  Streets. No person shall do any form of excavating, cutting, repairing, or paving work on any street within the city limits until he/she has made written application therefor to the city secretary, on blanks to be furnished, and has received a permit to do the same. Said application shall describe the character of the work or repairing proposed to be done, together with the exact location of same, and shall be signed by the person applying for same. The permit to proceed with the work shall be issued by the city clerk in duplicate, the original to be handed to the party applying therefor, and the duplicate together with the application to be filed in the city office as a permanent record. 
(b)  Sidewalks. In addition to complying with all the provisions set out above for work on streets, a permit fee, as set forth in the fee schedule found in appendix A to this Code, shall be paid before such a permit shall be granted for repairs of sidewalks, driveways, etc. 
(Code 1992, § 3.805)  
Sec. 35-88. - Bond requirements. 
All persons (except the city and those with a valid and current franchise agreement with the city) desiring to do any work in connection with the city streets and sidewalks, shall file a petition in the city office giving the name of every person connected with such business, asking to be registered as a paving contractor; and shall execute and deliver to the city a bond in the sum of $1,000.00, payable to the city, with two or more good and sufficient sureties thereon, or a bond regularly issued by an approved surety company, which bond shall be conditioned as follows: 
(1)  Said bond shall be conditioned that all work done upon any street within the corporate limits shall be done in a good and workmanlike manner, and in accordance with this article; and that the city shall be fully indemnified and held whole and harmless from any and all costs, expense and/or damage including workmen's compensation claims, whether real or asserted, on account of any injury done to any person or property in the prosecution of work or consequence of doing such work, or that may arise out of, or be occasioned by the performance of such work. In the event that any cuts, excavations, repair or paving is not done in accordance with the specifications herein set forth, the superintendent shall give notice to such individual, firm, partnership or corporation to that effect, and in case of failure or default in the curing of the defect so pointed out after such notice, and after the expiration of a reasonable time, 15 days time shall be deemed reasonable time for the beginning of any such work, the superintendent shall report such fact to the governing body of the city and the governing body may, thereupon, order the restoration of said street at the cost to such person making such excavation, cut, repair or paving; and the statement of the cost, as furnished by the superintendent shall be prima facie evidence against such person making such excavation, cut, repair or doing any such paving. 
(2)  Said bond shall be deemed a continuous obligation against the principal and sureties thereon, until the entire amount therein provided for shall be decreased in amount on account of any of the conditions of the same whereupon the governing body shall require, upon notice to the principal by the superintendent, of such facts, an additional bond to be given by any such person doing any such street work, conditioned in accordance with this article, and in an amount sufficient, when added to the unexhausted amount of the original bond, to equal at all times the original sum provided in this section. In no case shall any individual, firm or corporation engage in any work pertaining to the city streets without having on file, and accepted by the city, a bond in the amount herein fixed. 
(3)  Said bond shall run for a period of one year, and shall be renewed on or before its expiration date. No street work shall be done by, and no permits issued to any person, firm or corporation, unless his/her or its bond is in full force and effect. 
(Code 1992, § 3.806)  
Sec. 35-89. - Barricades and warning devices to be used at closed streets. 
When any section of the street or sidewalk is closed to traffic, the person doing such work shall furnish and maintain at each end of the closed section and at all intersecting roads within the section, barricades, adequate warning and directing signs, lights and red flags. 
(Code 1992, § 3.807)  
Sec. 35-90. - Maintenance of detours. 
Any individual, firm or corporation doing any work on the city streets or sidewalks shall do such work as may be necessary to provide and maintain detours and facilities for public travel, to include pedestrian detours when work on sidewalks is in progress, at his/her or its expense. The safety and convenience of the public are deemed to be of first importance. 
(Code 1992, § 3.808)  
Sec. 35-91. - Notification to utilities of pending work. 
It shall be the duty of any person setting out to do any work on the streets or sidewalks to notify in writing the water, sewer, gas and light companies of the exact nature and location of such work. Such notice must be made at least five days prior to the commencement of such work. Any repairs, connection, etc. required to be made to utility lines shall be made under the supervision of the utility concerned. 
(Code 1992, § 3.809)  
Sec. 35-92. - Breaks in utility lines; notice; liability. 
(a)  During the progress of such work, all utility lines shall remain connected and in proper working order whenever practicable. Whenever it shall be necessary to disconnect utility lines, all persons being served by such utility lines shall be notified at least four hours prior to such disconnection, by the person doing such work. 
(b)  When breaks are made in utility lines by accident, the person conducting the work (unless it be the city) shall be liable for resulting damage under the rules of ordinary liability. 
(Code 1992, § 3.810)  
Sec. 35-93. - Specifications. 
(a)  Backfilling. As soon as practicable, all spaces excavated shall be backfilled. Backfill material shall be free from large or frozen lumps, wood, or other extraneous material. The portion of backfill which will not support any portion of the completed roadbed or embankment shall be placed in layers not more than ten inches in depth (loose measurement) and shall be compacted to a density comparable with the adjacent, undisturbed material. That portion of the backfill which will support any portion or the roadbed or embankment shall be placed in uniform layers not to exceed six inches depth (loose measurement) and each layer compacted to a density comparable with the adjacent undisturbed material. Each layer of backfill material, if dry, shall be wetted uniformly to the moisture content required to obtain the specified density, and shall be compacted to the required density by means of mechanical tamps or rammers, except that the use of rolling equipment of the type generally used in compacting embankments will be permitted on those portions which are accessible to such equipment. These provisions shall be construed to require the mechanical compaction, by means of either rolling equipment or mechanical tamps or rammers, of all backfill and embankment. No backfill shall be done except in the presence of the street superintendent or one of his/her authorized employees. 
(b)  Flexible base. In addition to backfilling any excavation as herein provided, there shall be placed immediately below the surface of any street to be paved a foundation course for surface course consisting of caliches and stone material. The material shall be obtained from approved sources. It shall consist of argillaceous limestone, calcareous clay particles, with or without stone, conglomerate, gravel, sand or other granular materials. The material shall be approved by the superintendent at the source. This material shall be placed to a depth of at least eight inches and shall be compacted as hereinabove set forth. 
(c)  Grades. All grades must conform with the requirements established by the city. 
(d)  Street topping. In addition to the backfilling and flexible base herein provided for, any person doing any work upon any street within the city limits shall place a minimum of one inch hot mix cold lay asphaltic concrete (preferably type DD) in any and all openings made upon the asphalt surfacings of any such street. 
(Code 1992, § 3.811)  
Sec. 35-94. - Requirement to clean up. 
Upon completion of the work, such person shall clean, remove rubbish and temporary structure from the streets, restore in an acceptable manner all property, both public and private, which has been damaged during the prosecution of the work, and leave the site of the work in a neat and presentable condition throughout. 
(Code 1992, § 3.812)  
Sec. 35-95. - Superintendent not to be held liable. 
In carrying out the provisions contained herein, there shall be no liability upon the street superintendent or his/her authorized assistants, either personally or otherwise. 
(Code 1992, § 3.813)  
Secs. 35-96—35-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - PURPOSE, SCOPE, DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 35-121. - General purpose. 
The purpose of this Ordinance is to: 
(1)  Assist in the management of Facilities placed in, on, over, under, or above the Public Rights-of-Way in order to minimize the congestion, inconvenience, deterioration, visual impact and other adverse effects, and the costs to the citizens resulting from the placement of Facilities within the Public Rights-of-Way; 
(2)  Govern the use and occupancy of the Public Rights-of-way; 
(3)  Assist the City in its efforts to protect the public health, safety and welfare; 
(4)  Conserve the limited physical capacity of the Public Rights-of-way held in public trust by the City; 
(5)  Preserve the physical integrity of the streets and highways; 
(6)  Control the orderly flow of vehicles and pedestrians; 
(7)  Keep track of the different entities using the Public Rights-of-Way to prevent interference between them; 
(8)  Assist in scheduling common trenching and street cuts; and 
(9)  Protect the safety, security, appearance, and condition of the Public Rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.1, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-122. - Scope and authority. 
This Ordinance applies to all Persons that place Facilities in any manner, in, on, over, or above a Public Right-of-Way. Compensation for use of the Public Rights-of-way shall be paid in accordance with all applicable law, including, but not limited to, cable providers, in accordance with the Federal Cable Act, 47 USC § 541, et seq.; certificated telecommunication providers, in accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 283 and 284; distributors of natural gas in accordance with V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 182.025, or applicable franchise ordinance or agreement; investor-owned electric utilities in accordance with V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 33.008, or applicable franchise ordinance or agreement; and/or in accordance with Tex. Civil Statute Ann., Art. 1175(1), all as applicable to any Person using in any manner the City's Public Rights-of-way. Provided, however, that if a Person is subject to a valid franchise agreement or ordinance approved or adopted by the City, the terms of that franchise agreement or ordinance, if in conflict with the provisions hereof, shall govern the franchisee's rights and obligations with regard to use and placement of Facilities in, on, over, under, or above the City's Public Rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.2, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-123. - Conformance with all laws. 
This ordinance is passed subject to applicable provisions of the Constitution and Laws of the United States and the State of Texas and the Charter and the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fredericksburg. This Ordinance shall in no way affect or impair the City's rights, obligations, or remedies under the Public Utility Regulatory Act of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.3, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-124. - Use of city's rights-of-way only. 
This Ordinance addresses only use of the City's Public Rights-of-Way. This Ordinance does not authorize any Person, including any Permittee to install or maintain attachments in or on other City property and facilities, including without limitation conduits, buildings, poles, and towers. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.4, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-125. - Reservation of right. 
The City reserves the right to lay, and permit to be laid, sewer, water, and other pipe lines, wires, cables, and conduits, and to do and permit to be done any underground or aboveground work that may be necessary or proper in, across, along, over, under, or above a street, alley, highway, public place, or other Public Right-of-way. The City also reserves the right to change any curb, sidewalk, or grade of a street. In permitting this work to be done, the City shall not be liable to a Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-way, for any resulting damage, but nothing herein shall relieve any other person or entity from responsibility for damages to Permittee's or such Person's Facilities. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.5, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-126. - Private easements. 
Nothing in this Ordinance and no action by City shall be construed to offer, grant or approve any right or license to use a private easement in any manner, or to affix any Facility within such easement without the consent of the owner of the property to which the easement is appurtenant, unless otherwise allowed by law. City has no obligation to expand or obtain rights in such easement on Permittee's behalf. It is the sole obligation of Permittee to obtain the necessary consent or additional easement rights, if any, at Permittee's own expense; provided, however poles may not be erected in areas prohibited by City design standards or in areas where other Person's Facilities are underground. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.6, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-127. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandon and its derivatives mean the facilities have been left in an unused or non-functioning condition for more than 90 consecutive days. 
Antenna means communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services. 
Applicable codes mean the most current building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing and fire codes codified in Chapter 7 of the City's Development Code and amended therein. 
Cable service is defined in 47 U.S.C. Section 522(6). 
Cable service provider means a person who provides cable service and has been issued a state-issued certificate of franchise authority from the Public Utility Commission of Texas or its successor under V.T.C.A., Utilities Code ch. 66. 
Certificated Telecommunications Provider has the meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.002(2), for which the PUC has issued a certificate of operating authority or service provider certificate of operating authority to provide local exchange telephone service or voice service. 
City means the City of Fredericksburg, Texas and the City's officers and employees. 
Collocate and collocation mean the installation, mounting, maintenance, modification, operation, or replacement of network nodes in a public right-of-way on or adjacent to a pole. 
Decorative pole means a streetlight pole specially designed and placed for aesthetic purposes and on which no appurtenances or attachments, other than temporary holiday or special event attachments, have been placed or are permitted to be placed pursuant to this article. 
Design Manual means the Design Manual for Siting and Criteria for the Installation of Wireless Micro Network Nodes, Network Nodes, Node Support Poles and Related Ground Equipment Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284. 
Director means the City of Fredericksburg's Director of Public Works and Utilities and his or her designee. 
Facilities means a pole, conduit, pipeline, line, wire, cable, fiber, duct spaces, manholes, poles, conduits, underground and overhead passageways, equipment, antenna, structures, or facility plant and appurtenances of any kind whatsoever, and includes Utility Poles, Transport Facilities, Micro Network Nodes, Network Nodes, Node Support Poles, and related ground equipment. 
Historic district means an area that is zoned or otherwise designated as a historic district under City ordinance or state or federal law to include the historic shopping district overlay and the area within 1,000 feet of the property boundary line of a property which is designated as a Historic landmark under the City's historic zoning ordinance(s). 
Historic landmark means a site or structure recognized by the City, state or federal government. 
Law means common law or a federal, state, or local law, statute, code, rule, regulation, order, or ordinance. 
Macro tower means a guyed or self-supported pole or monopole that supports or is capable of supporting antennas and does not exceed the height parameters prescribed by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.003. 
Micro network node means a network node that is not larger in dimension than 24 inches in length, 15 inches in width, and 12 inches in height, and that has an exterior antenna, if any, not longer than 11 inches. 
Municipal Park means an area that is zoned or otherwise designated by municipal code as a public park for the purpose of recreational activity. 
Municipally owned utility pole means a utility pole owned or operated by a municipally owned utility, as defined by V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 11.003, and located in a public right-of-way. 
Network node means equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless communications between user equipment and a communications network. The term includes: 
(1)  Equipment associated with wireless communications; 
(2)  A radio transceiver, an antenna, a battery-only backup power supply, and comparable equipment, regardless of technological configuration; and 
(3)  Coaxial or fiber-optic cable that is immediately adjacent to and directly associated with a particular collocation. 
The term does not include an electric generator, pole or macro tower. 
Network provider means a: 
(1)  Wireless service provider; or 
(2)  Person that does not provide wireless services and that is not an electric utility but builds or installs on behalf of a wireless service provider network nodes or node support poles or any other structure that supports or is capable of supporting a network node. 
Node support pole means a pole installed by a network provider for the primary purpose of supporting a network node. 
Park means an area that is zoned or otherwise designated by the City as a public park for the purpose of recreational activity. 
Permit means a written authorization for the use of the public right-of-way or collocation on a service pole (as to network providers) before a user of the public right-of-way may perform an action or initiate, continue or complete a project. A "permit" includes all permits required by this article and applicable codes adopted by the City. 
Pole means a service pole, municipally owned utility pole, node support pole, or utility pole. 
Private easement means an easement or other real property right that is only for the benefit of the grantor and grantee and their successors and assigns. 
Public property means public rights-of-way, bridges, tunnels, and similar property in which the City holds any property interest or exercises any rights of management or control. 
Public right-of-way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easement in which the municipality has an interest. The term does not include: 
(1)  A private easement; or 
(2)  The airwaves above a public right-of-way with regard to wireless telecommunications. 
Service pole means a pole owned or operated by the City and located in the public right-of-way, including a: 
(1)  Pole that supports traffic control functions; 
(2)  Structure for signage; 
(3)  Pole that supports lighting, other than a decorative pole; and 
(4)  Pole or similar structure owned or operated by the City and supporting only network nodes. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a public right-of-way improved and designated for or ordinarily used for pedestrian travel or pedestrian and bicycle travel. 
Street means that portion of a public right-of-way improved and designated for or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
Substantially similar means that the: 
(1)  New or upgraded network node, including the antenna or other equipment element, will not be more than ten percent larger than the existing network node, provided that the increase may not result in the network need exceeding the size limitation provided by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.003; and 
(2)  New or upgraded pole will not be more than ten percent higher than the existing pole, provided that the increase may not result in the pole exceeding the height limitations provided by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.203. 
Traffic Signal means any device, whether manually, electrically, or mechanically operated by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
Transport facility means each transmission path physically within a public right-of-way, extending with a physical line from a network node directly to the network, for the purpose of providing backhaul for network nodes. 
Underground Utility means an area where poles, overhead wires, and associated overhead or above ground structures have been removed and buried or have been approved for burial underground. 
Utility pole means a pole that provides: 
(1)  Electric distribution with a voltage rating of not more than 34.5 kilovolts; or 
(2)  Services of a telecommunications provider, as defined by V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 51.002. 
Video Service has the meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 66.002(10). 
Video service provider has the meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 66.002(11), for which the PUC has issued a state-issued certificate of franchise authority to provide video service. 
Voice service has the meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.002. 
Wireless service means any service, using licensed or unlicensed wireless spectrum, including the use of Wi-Fi, whether at a fixed location or mobile, provided to the public using a network node. 
Wireless service provider means a person that provides wireless service to the public. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 1.7, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-128. - Decorative Poles. 
(a)  Appurtenances and attachments. No appurtenances or attachments, other than temporary holiday or special event attachments, subject to the provisions of the City's sign ordinance, are permitted to be placed on decorative poles. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Secs. 35-129—35-140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 35-141. - Prohibition. 
No Person shall construct any Facilities in City's Public Rights-of-Way except as authorized by this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.1, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-142. - Use of existing and future poles. 
To the extent utility poles owned by any utility are present in the particular section of a Public Right-of-way, and regardless of the side of the street the same are on, a Permittee that intends to place its Facilities in the Public Rights-of-Way shall use such existing poles unless it establishes that use of existing poles creates a safety hazard and it obtains written approval from City to install new poles, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld. Applicant shall obtain all requisite permits and enter all necessary pole use agreements for use of such existing utility poles whether owned by City or a third party. All excavations and other construction in the Public Rights-of-Way shall be conducted so as to minimize interference with the use of public and private property. Any Facilities placed within the Public Rights-of-Way that are suspended in any manner above ground shall either be placed on existing poles or equipment or be suspended at a height not less than 22 feet above ground level, unless otherwise approved by the Director, but in no event less than 15 feet, except to the extent state law controls. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.2, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-143. - Use of above ground facilities and poles by third party. 
In the event a third party or City desires to install above-ground Facilities in the same Public Right-of-way in which Facilities are installed or placed, the owner of the same shall allow such third party or City to use such Facilities, and shall offer a reasonable agreement for the use of the same and provided such third party or City enters into said use agreement. This Ordinance does not convey any right to any Person to attach any Facilities to any utility pole owned or controlled by the City without a separate pole use agreement. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.3, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-144. - Service pole requirements. 
(a)  Public safety and adherence to all applicable engineering standards shall be considered paramount in the design and installation of all poles, guys, and other overhead conductors, cables, light guides, and equipment placed with Public Rights-of-Way. 
(b)  The Director shall be the final arbiter of adequate design and installation, and any Person seeking to attach Facilities to the City's utility poles shall provide the City upon demand all necessary engineering documentation and calculations to demonstrate the adequacy of those designs. 
(c)  No poles, guys, equipment, conductors, cables, light guides or other above ground equipment shall be allowed to deteriorate to a point where it no longer meets design strength, lacks structural integrity, lacks clearance under current surrounding land-use conditions, or presents a likelihood of failure. 
(d)  No poles, guys, messenger strands, conductors, cables, light guides or equipment shall remain in place when no longer in use, except where plans demonstrate to the City that such equipment will be used within 12 months from the date on which such equipment is no longer being used. Where such use does not materialize within such time frame, the unused Facilities shall be removed within 30 days from the end of the twelve-month period. 
(e)  No longer than at ten-year intervals, at the expense of the Permittee all wooden poles owned by Permittee shall be examined by an independent third party specializing in the long-term maintenance of utility poles and where design strength is determined to no longer be adequate, replaced within 90 days. Proof of same shall be provided to Director. 
(f)  Poles that are replaced by the City due to lack of maintenance, shall become the property of the City. 
(g)  All poles, except those explicitly marked as being owned and maintained by another Person shall be the property of the City. 
(h)  No Person shall attach messenger strands, guys, conductors, or other equipment to any pole owned by the City that creates a net unbalanced force on the pole. 
(i)  Persons with poles, conductors, cables, light guides, guys, or other Facilities in the City's Public Rights-of-Way shall respond within 24 hours after notification of damaged or downed facilities. 
(j)  Persons with poles, conductors, cables, light guides, guys, or other Facilities in the City's Rights-of-Way shall be responsible for costs incurred by the City in taking corrective measures with regard to damaged or downed Facilities. 
(k)  Persons with poles, conductors, cables, light guides, guys, or other Facilities in the City's Rights-of-Way or attached to poles owned by the City shall be responsible to transfer, relocate, or modify such Facilities due to pole maintenance, relocation, repairs, or replacement within 30 days from notice by the City of the need to maintain, relocate, repair, or replace the Person's Facilities. 
(l)  Multiple parallel pole lines on one side of a Public Right-of-way are prohibited, even in circumstances where the original pole line is installed off the Public Right-of-way in an adjacent easement. 
(m)  The installation of new poles, or the use of poles abandoned by the City within pole lines owned by the City is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.4, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-145. - Underground facilities. 
The City may withhold its permission to install new poles and require underground placement in any area in which its Facilities, or those of other providers are placed or are to be placed underground, unless the Applicant makes a compelling demonstration that, in any specific instance, such requirement is not reasonable or feasible. The cost of underground installation or the time required to negotiate a joint use agreement shall not be considered a compelling reason. 
(1)  Facilities shall be installed underground where other entities' existing Facilities are already underground. A Person seeking to install Facilities in the Public Right-of-Way shall make a reasonable determination as to whether space is available to accommodate the Person's new Facilities. A negative determination shall not relieve the Person of the responsibility to underground its Facilities in underground utility areas to the degree reasonably feasible. Previously installed aerial Facilities shall be placed underground in concert, and on a cost-sharing basis, with other entities utilizing the Public Right-of-way when such other entities convert from aerial to underground construction. 
(2)  Underground conduits and ducts shall be installed in the Public Rights-of-Way between the adjacent property line and the curb line unless otherwise directed by the City. 
(3)  Conduits and ducts shall be installed parallel with the curb line and shall cross the Public Rights-of-Way perpendicular to the Public Rights-of-Way centerline unless otherwise directed by the City. 
(4)  Conduits and ducts shall be installed by trenchless excavation or directional boring when placing these facilities under paved Public Rights-of-Way or driveway crossings to avoid motor vehicle interruptions, unless otherwise directed by the City. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.5, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-146. - Relocation and removal of facilities. 
(a)  Within 60 days following written notice from the City, any person owning facilities located in the public right-of-way, must, as directed by the City, and at the person's sole cost, temporarily or permanently remove, relocate, change or alter the position of any of their facilities that are in the public right-of-way whenever the City determines that the removal, relocation, change or alteration is necessary for the construction, repair, maintenance, installation, completion, relocations, or widening of any City improvement, facilities, or equipment, in or upon the public right-of-way. Relocation of a Micro Network Node, Network Node, Node Support Pole, and related ground equipment must comply with the provisions of this article regarding spacing and other limitations. 
(b)  If a person does not remove or relocate its facilities as required by subsection (a) of this section, the City may remove the facilities at the person's sole cost and expense, without further notice to the person and within 30 days following receipt of an invoice from the City, the person shall reimburse the City for its reasonable expenses incurred in the removal or relocation of the facilities. 
(c)  If the Director determines that there is imminent danger to the public health, safety and welfare, the Director may immediately disconnect, remove or relocate a person's facilities in the public right-of-way at the person's sole cost. The person shall reimburse the City for its reasonable expenses incurred in the removal or relocation of the facilities within 30 days following receipt of an invoice from the City. 
(d)  If a person owning a facility in the public right-of-way removes or relocates the facility at its discretion, the person shall notify the City in writing not less than ten business days prior to the removal or relocation. A relocation must comply with the provisions of this article. The person shall obtain all permits required for the removal or relocation of the person's facilities prior to the removal or relocation. 
(e)  If a person does not remove or relocate its facilities as required by subsections (a) and (b) of this [section], the City may remove the facilities at the person's sole cost and expense, without further notice to the person and within 30 days following issuance of an invoice from the City, the person shall reimburse the City for its reasonable expenses incurred in the removal or relocation of the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.6, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-147. - Street widening, straightening, or changes in grade. 
Whenever, by reason of street widening, straightening, or changes in the grade or contours of a street, alley, or other public way, it is deemed that Permittee's Facilities located in the City's Public Rights-of-Way, or the Facilities of any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, are in conflict with such activity, and for such reason it is deemed necessary to remove, alter, change, adapt, or conform the Facilities to accommodate such activity, Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, shall make the alterations or changes as soon as practical but no later than 90 days following the request from the City, unless the Director extends such period. Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, shall undertake such action without claim for reimbursement from or damages against the City. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.7, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-148. - Excavations. 
A Person excavating in the City's Public Rights-of-Way shall perform excavations and other construction in the Public Rights-of-Way in accordance with all applicable City requirements, including the obligation to use trenchless technology whenever commercially economical and practical and consistent with obligations on other similar users of the Public Right-of-Way. The City may waive the requirement of trenchless technology if it determines that, based upon information provided to the City by the Person seeking to excavate, the particular field conditions warrant a waiver. A Person shall follow all reasonable construction directions given by the City in order to minimize any such interference. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.8, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-149. - Time to close excavations. 
All holes, trenches, and excavations for repairs shall be covered at least with asphalt as soon as possible, not to exceed an opening and closing period of 48 hours in high traffic areas. Temporary repairs are acceptable within the 48 hours, and then the permanent repairs, including repairs for non-high traffic areas shall be performed within 14 days. High traffic areas shall be defined as any state highway, farm to market road, ranch road, or any collector or arterial road as designated on the City's Transportation Plan. City may designate additional areas as high-traffic from time to time. Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, shall promptly restore to its previous condition and to the reasonable satisfaction of the City, a street, alley, or public right-of-way excavated by it. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.9, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-150. - Coordination of trenching and excavation. 
A Person shall use its best efforts to coordinate joint trenching with any other Persons whose Facilities are in and along the same Public Rights-of-Way where construction may be performed in a time frame reasonably similar to the other Person's construction timetable. The Director may mandate such coordination to the fullest extent allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.10, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-151. - Removal of dangerous facilities. 
The City may require Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, to repair, remove, or abate any Facilities or other structure or equipment that are no longer being used, or for which Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, has no reasonable plans for future uses, or are unnecessarily dangerous to life or property, and in case Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, after notice, fails or refuses to act within a reasonable time, the City may remove or abate the same at the expense of Permittee or such Person, without compensation or liability for damages to Permittee or such Person. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.11, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-152. - Plans for ongoing work. 
To the extent made, plans for ongoing repair, maintenance, and improvements which involve cutting into paved City roads or streets shall be submitted to the Director on an annual basis, no later than April 1 of each year, and updated based upon any changes. This does not require the public disclosure of proprietary information, such as equipment or customer specific information. Such information may be designated confidential, and to the extent allowed by law, will be kept confidential by the City. Alternatively, a Person may meet with the appropriate representative of Public Works each calendar quarter to provide such plans to the extent made. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.12, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-153. - Notice that permittee is ready to proceed. 
Once a permit is issued, Permittee shall notify the Director at least 24 hours in advance that construction in the Public Rights-of-Way is ready to proceed by a person or its representative. Information signs in conformity with the Texas Department of Transportation Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices—Notices stating the identity of the person doing the work and their telephone number shall be placed at the location where construction is to occur 48 hours prior to the beginning of work in the Public Rights-of-Way and shall continue to be posted at the location during the entire time the work is occurring and/or until permanent repairs are completed. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.13, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-154. - Erosion control measures and warning signs. 
Erosion control measures and advance warning signs, markers, cones, and barricades must be in place before work begins. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.14, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-155. - Closure of lanes in major thoroughfares. 
Lane closures on major thoroughfares will be limited to between 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. unless the Director grants prior approval. Arrow boards will be required on lane closures with all barricades, advance warning signs, and 36-inch reflector cones placed according to the specifications of the City. Working hours in the Public Rights-of-Way are limited to the hours between 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. Work to be performed at other times or on Saturday must be approved by the Director in advance. Directional boring is permitted only Monday through Friday 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. No work in the Public Rights-of-Way shall be performed except for emergencies, on Sunday's or on holidays. The Director may condition his or her approval or work times other than stated upon payment by Permittee of the City's overtime costs if any. 
(1)  Within 14 days of completion of excavation, construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, removal, maintenance or repair of Facilities, or other work in the Public Rights-of-Way, a Permittee shall temporarily restore and repair the Public Rights-of-Way in accordance with the City Code. 
(2)  Within 30 calendar days after completion of work in the Public Rights-of-Way, the Permittee shall permanently restore, replace, relay and/or repair the surface, base, curbs, drainage systems, irrigation systems, landscape treatment or other City Facilities and infrastructure located on, in, over, under, or above any Public Rights-of-Way that has been excavated, altered or damaged by reason of the excavation, construction, installation, expansion, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, removal, maintenance or repair of the Permittee's Facilities in accordance with existing standards of the City in effect at the time of the work. 
(3)  Whenever a Permittee disturbs or destroys any right-of-way markers or monuments, it shall restore the same within thirty-days after construction has ceased. A Permittee shall furnish three sets of drawings, blueline or blackline, detailing the restored monumentation. State Plane Coordinates shall be shown for all monumentation (existing or restored). The drawings shall be signed (original signature), sealed and certified, by a Registered Professional Land Surveyor, and delivered to the Director for approval no later than 30 days after construction has ceased. 
(4)  Upon a showing of good cause, the City may at its sole discretion extend the time for restoration and repair of the Public Rights-of-Way under this subsection. 
(5)  Unless the Permittee provides a recently dated photograph or a video of the Public Rights-of-Way before the construction, the condition of the Public Rights-of-Way before construction is presumed in good condition, and shall be restored to good condition. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.15, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-156. - Failure to repair. 
Upon failure of a Permittee to perform any such repair or replacement work after five days written notice has been given by the City to the Permittee, and in the event repairs have not been initiated during such five-day period, the City may repair such portion of the Public Rights-of-Way as may have been disturbed by the Person, its contractors or agents. Upon receipt of an invoice from the City, the Permittee shall reimburse the City for the costs so incurred within 30 calendar days from the date of the City invoice. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.16, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-157. - Repairs after twelve months. 
Should the Director reasonably determine, within one year from the date of the completion of the repair work, that the surface, base, curbs, drainage systems, irrigation systems, landscape treatment or other City Facilities and infrastructure located on, in, over, under, or above any Public Rights-of-Way requires additional restoration, replacement or repair work to meet existing standards of the City, a Permittee shall perform such additional restoration, replacement or repair work to the satisfaction of the City, subject to all City remedies as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.17, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-158. - Repairs by city. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the Director determines that the failure of a Permittee to properly repair or restore the Public Rights-of-Way constitutes a safety hazard to the public, the City may undertake emergency repairs and restoration efforts to Permittee's Facilities, after emergency notice has been provided, to the extent reasonable under the circumstances, and the Permittee has failed to respond within a reasonable time specified by the City. Upon receipt of an invoice from the City, a Permittee shall promptly reimburse the City for all costs incurred by the City within 30 calendar days from the date of the City invoice. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.18, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-159. - Emergency repairs. 
If the Director declares an emergency with regard to the health and safety of the citizens and requests by written notice the removal or abatement of Facilities, a Permittee shall remove or abate the Permittee's Facilities by the deadline provided in the Director's request. The Permittee and the City shall cooperate to the extent possible to assure continuity of service. If the Permittee, after notice, fails or refuses to act, the City may remove or abate the Facility, at the sole cost and expense of the Permittee, without paying compensation to the Permittee and without the City incurring liability for damages to Permittee's Facilities or due to Losses by Permittee or its customers. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.19, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-160. - Emergency conditions. 
Except in the case of customer service interruptions and imminent harm to property or Persons ("Emergency Conditions"), a Person may not excavate the pavement of a street or Public Rights-of-Way without first complying with City requirements. The Director shall be notified as promptly as possible regarding work performed under such Emergency Conditions, and the Permittee shall comply with the requirements of City standards and of this Ordinance for the restoration, replacement or repair of the Public Rights-of-Way, and shall supply all information required by an initial application within 14 days following the emergency work. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.20, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-161. - Termination of use. 
If Permittee, or any Person using the City's Public Rights-of-Way, ceases providing services over its Facilities, Permittee shall promptly begin the process of removing all Facilities from City's Public Rights-of-Way. All such Facilities shall be removed within 60 days after the date of cessation of services over the Facilities, or within such time as City may approve in writing. 
(Ord. No. 24-109, § 2.21, 9-2-2014)  
Sec. 35-162. - Violations. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to knowingly construct, place, maintain, or operate any line, wire, pipe, conduit, equipment, antenna, pole, structure, or facility in a public right-of-way or other public property for the purpose of providing water, wastewater, electrical, natural gas, or other unauthorized service to any person, without first receiving the consent of the City. The City may, as a condition of its giving its consent, require the person requesting such use to enter into a written agreement with the City containing the conditions under which the use of the public right-of-way will be permitted. 
(b)  Except in cases of emergency, it is unlawful for any person to knowingly dig up, break, cut, excavate, drill or tunnel in or on any public right-of-way without first obtaining a right-of-way work permit from the City. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to knowingly install or place any facilities in a public right-of-way or make use of the public right-of-way for any purpose not authorized by state law or the City, as applicable, in accordance with City ordinances. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person doing work under a permit to violate a provision of the permit. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person to continue work under a permit after receiving a stop work order or receiving notice that a stop work order has been issued or to resume the work or activity until the Director withdraws the stop work order. 
(f)  Each unauthorized use of the public right-of-way or other public property is a separate offense. And each day a violation continues is a separate offense and is subject to the Penalty provisions in Section 1-6, and other applicable penalty provisions in the City of Fredericksburg Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-163. - Effect on other Utilities and Providers. 
(a)  Gas and Electric Franchises. To the extent of a conflict between this article and a gas or electric franchise existing on the date of this ordinance, the gas or electric franchise ordinance shall control. 
(b)  Other utilities and telecommunications providers. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.252, the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284 do not apply to the attachment of network nodes on poles or other structures owned by investor-owned electric utilities (V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 31.002), electric cooperatives (V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 11.003) telephone cooperatives (V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 162.003) or telecommunications providers (V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 51.002) and does not confer any new city authority over those utilities, cooperatives or providers. 
(c)  Cable service or video service providers. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.253, approval for the installation, placement, maintenance of operation of a network node or transport facility does not authorize: 
(1)  Cable services or video service to be provided without compliance with V.T.C.A., Utilities Code ch. 66; or 
(2)  Information service as defined by 47 U.S.C. Section 153(24) to be provided in the public right-of-way; or 
(3)  Telecommunications service as defined by 47 U.S.C. Section 153(53) to be provided in the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Wireless service providers. A wireless service provider, or its affiliate, that holds a cable or video franchise under V.T.C.A., Utilities Code ch. 66 is not required to obtain additional authorization or to pay any fees based on the provider's provision of wireless service over its network nodes. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.253(b)) 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
DIVISION 2.5. - WIRELESS MICRO NETWORK NODES, NETWORK NODES, NODE SUPPORT POLES AND RELATED GROUND EQUIPMENT IN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 35-164. - Right of Access. 
Subject to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, this Article, the Design Manual, and other applicable ordinances, a network provider may use the public rights-of-way to: 
(1)  Construct, modify, maintain, operate, relocate and remove a network node or node support pole; 
(2)  Modify or replace a utility pole or node support pole; and 
(3)  Collocate on a pole. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-165. - Prohibited or restricted areas. 
(a)  Prohibited areas. 
(1)  A network provider may not install a node support pole in a public right-of-way without the City's discretionary, nondiscriminatory, and written consent, if the public right-of-way is adjacent to a street or thoroughfare that is: 
a.  Not more than 50 feet wide; and 
b.  Adjacent to a single-family residential lot or other multifamily residences or undeveloped land that is designated for residential use by zoning or deed restrictions. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 284.104(a), (b)) 
(2)  A network provider may not install a node support pole in a public right-of-way in a park, without the City's discretionary, nondiscriminatory, and written consent. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 284.104(a), (b)) 
(b)  Historic districts and Historic landmark areas. A network provider must obtain a certificate of appropriateness under the administrative provisions of the City's historic zoning ordinance(s) from the City's Historic Preservation Officer before collocating network nodes or installing node support poles in historic districts. As a condition for approval, the network providers must provide design or concealment measures for the new network node or node support pole, as provided in the design manual. The network provider should explore the feasibility of using camouflage measures to improve the aesthetics of the network node, node support pole, or related ground equipment or any portion of the network node, node support pole or ground equipment to minimize the impact to the aesthetics in the historic district. Nothing in this subsection limits the City's authority to enforce historic preservation zoning regulations consistent with the preservation of local zoning authority under 47 U.S.C. Section 332(c)(7), the requirements for facility modifications under 47 U.S.C. Section 1455(a), or the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (16. U.S.C. Section 470 et seq.) and the regulations adopted to implement these laws. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.105) 
(c)  Undergrounding areas. A network provider, in relation to installation for which the City has approved a permit application, must comply with undergrounding requirements, including the City's ordinances, zoning regulations, state law, private deed restrictions, and other public or private restrictions that prohibit installing above-ground structures in a public right-of-way without first obtaining zoning or land use approval. Areas of the City may be designated from time to time by the City as underground areas in accordance with filed plats, or conversions of overhead to underground areas, as may be allowed by law. This subsection does not prohibit a network provider from replacing an existing structure. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.107) 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-166. - Design Manual. 
(a)  Adoption of design manual. The City Council adopts the Design Manual for Siting and Criteria for the Installation of Wireless Micro Network Nodes, Network Nodes, Node Support Poles and Related Ground Equipment Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284. A copy of the Design Manual is attached to the City of Fredericksburg Code of Ordinances as Appendix C. 
(b)  Revisions to design manual. The Director may from time-to-time add to, delete from, or revise the Design Manual without Council action if the revision: 
(1)  Does not conflict with a provision of state law or this Article; 
(2)  Is for the purpose of providing detailed or technical specifications, requirements, or procedures applicable to the matters regulated under this article, but does not implement new substantive regulations or requirements not addressed in this article; 
(3)  Is adopted in compliance with written procedures, as approved by the City Manager, that provide for public notice, an opportunity for public comment, and consideration of any public comments prior to adoption; and 
(4)  Is approved by the City Manager. 
(c)  Compliance with Design Manual. A network provider must comply with any applicable provisions of the Design Manual as a condition of approval of any application, permit, or other approval required under this article or the Design Manual. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-167. - Transport Facilities. 
(a)  A network provider that wants to connect a network node to the network using the public right-of-way may: 
(1)  Install its own transport facilities if it obtains a permit under this article and pays the public right-of-way rates in sections 5.505, 5.506, 5.507 and 5.508 in Appendix A; or 
(2)  Obtain transport service from a person that is paying municipal fees to occupy the public right-of-way that are the equivalent of not less than $28.00 per node per month. (Section 5.508, Appendix A; V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.055) 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-168. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees. The network provider must pay the Right-of-Way Construction Permit Application Fee and the Application Fee for Network Providers as provided in Sections 5.505 and 5.506 of Appendix A and any other applicable fees set forth in the City of Fredericksburg Code of Ordinances, to include other fees and rates established in Sections 5.507, and 5.508 in Appendix A. 
(b)  Notice of annual increase in public right-of-way rate. The City will provide written notice to the network provider of a new annual public right-of-way rate, adjusted as provided Section 5.507 in Appendix A, which shall apply to the first payment due to the City on or after 60 days following the notice. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-169. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits required by applicable codes. In addition to the Right-of-Way Construction Permit Application Fee and Application Fee for Network Providers, set forth in Sections 5.505 and 5.506 of Appendix A, the network provider must obtain all other applicable permit application fees set forth in the City of Fredericksburg Code of Ordinances, this Article, and Appendix A. 
(b)  Consolidated permits. A network provider that wants to install or collocate multiple network nodes inside the territorial jurisdiction of the City is entitled to file a consolidated permit application with the City for not more than 30 network nodes and receive permits for the installation or colocation of those network nodes. Each network node permit issued in a consolidated permit application is subject to a separate permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule in section 5.506 of Appendix A. (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.152) 
(c)  Issuance of permits. The permit(s) will be issued if the application complies with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284, this article, applicable codes and the design manual. 
(Ord. No. 27-011, § 2, 8-7-2017)  
Sec. 35-170. - Review process for applications.
