ARTICLE 11.701. - UTILITY DEPOSITS AND BILLING 
(a)  Deposits. 
(1)  Each customer shall pay to the City, at the time of making application for connection to the applicable system an amount as is set forth in Appendix A to this Code as security for the payment of the bills for utility service. This deposit is a combined deposit for any or all utilities for each customer. In lieu of a deposit, the City may accept a letter from another City or utility company which states that the customer has not defaulted or was late on payment for its services for a minimum period of the two most recent years, or, the City may accept a credit report from a national credit reporting service similarly showing no late payments for a period of the most recent two years. 
(2)  In the event a customer is delinquent in payment for regular monthly bills by more than 30 days, the City may apply the deposit to the payment of the delinquency along with any other fees such as late fees, unpaid connection fees and the like, and may require the customer to place an additional deposit up to two times the original deposit in order to continue its service. The City's right to apply the deposit and collect an additional fee is in addition to any other remedies the City has to collect payment and/or discontinue service. 
(3)  Utility deposits will be returned at such time as a customer has paid on time for twelve consecutive months upon request by the customer. Deposits, or any portion thereof remaining and not previously applied to a delinquent bill will be returned to the customer following payment of the final bill when service is terminated. 
(b)  Billing. 
(1)  Meters shall be read, as nearly as practical, at 30-day intervals, and bills rendered to customers as soon thereafter as practical. 
(2)  If a meter is not able to be read for any reason, the customer will be billed the average of the three previous months' bills and the billing adjusted when the meter is read. If the customer does not have a three month history, the customer will be billed at the rough average of similar properties as determined by the City. 
(3)  All accounts shall be payable at the designated City office. Failure to receive a bill does not exempt a customer from payment for service. 
(4)  Monthly billing for all utility services, as applicable, shall appear on one statement, and payment in full of the entire combined amount is required. 
(5)  All accounts not actually received by the City by the close of business on the 22nd day of the month shall have a ten percent penalty added to the current amount due. 
(6)  All accounts not actually received by the City by the close of business on the second day of the month following the issuance of the statement shall be subject to disconnection unless a payment agreement, satisfactory to the City, is made prior to such date. 
(7)  Any account for which a check is not paid or is returned, or for which an electronic or automatic withdrawal is denied for any reason, shall have a return check/denial fee added to it. The amount of such returned/denied payment fee shall be in accordance with the fee schedule in this Appendix A. 
(8)  For purposes of payment, penalties, fees and disconnection, if the due date falls upon a day when the City offices are closed, the following business day will be the due date. 
(9)  Following disconnection, it shall be unlawful for any person to reconnect said service or attempt to reconnect said service without a permit from the City. 
(10)  The City shall charge a reconnection fee as set forth in the fee schedule set forth in this Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013)  
ARTICLE 11.702. - ELECTRIC RATES[4] 
The following schedule of rates is adopted and fixed as the rates which shall be charged, commencing with the October 2015 bills to customers, for electric service furnished by the City Electric Department: 
(a)  Residential service electric rate: Schedule R. Rate 1. The City shall charge and collect for residential electric energy on the basis of the availability, application, character of service, monthly rate, power cost recovery, minimum charge, tax adjustment, and payment clauses of this tariff. 
(1)  Availability. This schedule is available throughout the entire territory served by the City. 
(2)  Application. This schedule is applicable to all electric service for domestic residential purposes to individual single-family private residences and multifamily residences or apartments served through a single meter, and which have not more than three living units. Any residential use containing more than three living units shall be billed under the commercial rate classes unless each unit has a separate rate meter. 
(3)  Character of service. 
A.  Service under this schedule shall be alternation current, 60 hertz, single phase, at the City's operation of standard available voltages. Where more than one meter is utilized for this service, each shall be computed separately for building services. 
B.  Where, in the opinion of the City, a customer's usage characteristics of service under this schedule do not conform with usual residential service characteristics due to customer's installation of demand intensive equipment including, but not limited to, electric motors and nonstandard water heating devices, demand meters may be installed by the City on any installation served under this schedule. 
(4)  Monthly rate. 
Customer charge: 	$11.03 PLUS 
	
Energy charge 	
Distribution charge: 	$0.0140 (all kWh per month) 
	
PCRF: 	See subsection (f) of this section (all kWh per month) 
	
 
(5)  Power cost recovery. The Power Cost Recovery Factor (PCRF) shall be calculated in accordance with the formula specified in the City's purchase power cost recovery factor clause, which is incorporated by reference as part of this rate schedule in subsection (f) below. 
(6)  Tax adjustment. The amount computed at the above monthly rate, as adjusted by the application of the monthly purchase power cost adjustment clause, shall be subject to taxes, assessments and surcharges imposed by any governmental authority, these charges being assessed on the basis of meters or customers or the price of or revenues from electric energy or service sold or volume of energy generated or purchased for sale or sold. 
(7)  Interruption of service. 
A.  The City will make reasonable provisions to ensure satisfactory and continuous service, but does not guarantee a continuous supply of electrical energy and shall not be liable for damage occasioned by interruptions of service or failure to commence delivery caused by an act of God, or the public enemy, or for any cause reasonably beyond its control including, but not limited to, the failure or breakdown of generating or transmitting facilities, floods, fire, strikes, or action or order of agency having jurisdiction in the premises, or for interruptions which are necessary for inspection, repair, or changes in generation equipment or transmission and distribution systems. 
B.  The customer shall notify the City immediately of any defects, troubles or accident which may in any way affect the delivery of power by the City to the customer. 
(b)  General service nondemand electric rate: Schedule Commercial/Secondary, Rate 2. The City shall charge and collect for Secondary with less than 300 kw demand electric energy on the basis of the availability, application, character of service, monthly rate, power cost recovery minimum charge, tax adjustment, and payment clauses of the tariff. 
(1)  Availability. This schedule is available throughout the entire territory served by the City of Fredericksburg. 
(2)  Application. This schedule is applicable to all business, commercial and income producing electric service (including residential with one meter and over three living units) exclusively for lighting, power, and any other purpose served through a single meter with a maximum annual demand which has occurred during the most recent 12-month period of less than 300 kw for which no other specific rate schedule is applicable. 
(3)  Character of service. Service under this schedule shall be single phase or three phase, 60 hertz, alternation current as the City's option of standard voltages. Where more than one meter is utilized for this service, each shall be computed separately for billing purposes. 
(4)  Monthly rate. 
Customer charge: 	$33.12 PLUS 
	
Energy charge 	
	
Distribution: 	$0.011742 (All kWh per month) 
	
PCRF: 	See subsection (f) of this section (all kWh per month) 
	
 
(5)  Power cost recovery. The Power Cost Recovery Factor (PCRF) shall be calculated in accordance with the formula specified in the City's purchase power cost recovery factor clause, which is incorporated by reference as a part of the rate schedule in subsection (f) below. 
(6)  Tax adjustment. The amount computed as the above monthly rate, as adjusted by the application of the monthly purchase power cost adjustment clause, shall be subject to taxes, assessments and surcharges imposed by any governmental authority, these charges being assessed on the basis of meters or customers or the price of or revenues from electric energy or service sold or volume of energy generated or purchased for sale or sold.

A. (3)  Character of service. Service under this schedule shall be single phase or three phase, 60 hertz, alternating current at standard available voltages. Where more than one meter is utilized for this service, each shall be computed separately for billing purposes, unless installed by the City for reliability and/or capacity requirements.

LCRATAD = Lower Colorado River Authority monthly wholesale billing total amount due

LCRAKWH = Lower Colorado River Authority monthly wholesale total adjusted meter consumption 
AEPTAD = AEP Energy Partners, Inc monthly wholesale total adjusted meter consumption

ARTICLE 14.000. - GARBAGE AND TRASH FEES 
 
Sec. 14.100. - Garbage Collection Rates. 
(a)  Each commercial customer participating in the automated garbage collection, and each owner or occupant of each residence within the city limits, shall be charged the following sum per month for each automated bulk garbage container: 
(1)  Thirty-two gallon bulk container shall be $11.00 per container. 
(2)  Sixty-four gallon bulk container shall be $12.50 per container. 
(3)  Ninety-six gallon bulk container shall be $14.00 per container. 
(b)  Occupants of apartment or multi-tenant complexes within the city limits whose individual units are billed for any other city utilities shall be charged $12.50 per individual dwelling unit per month. 
(c)  Apartments or multi-tenant complexes within the city limits whose individual units are not billed for any other city utilities and, at the discretion of the Director of Public Works or his designee, require the use of a City of Fredericksburg dumpster, shall be charged the following sum per dumpster per month, based upon collection service of four times per month: 
(1)  Ninety-six-gallon bulk container shall be $28.00 per container. 
(2)  Three-yard dumpster shall be $72.30 per container. 
(3)  Four-yard dumpster shall be $85.50 per container. 
Any additional collection shall be charged at the rate of $28.00 for a ninety-six-gallon bulk container, $72.30 for a three-yard dumpster, and $85.50 for a four-yard dumpster for each container for each pick-up. 
(d)  Businesses within the city limits that require the use of a City of Fredericksburg container, shall be charged the following sum per container per month, based upon collection service of four times per month: 
(1)  Ninety-six-gallon bulk container shall be $28.00 per container. 
(2)  Three-yard dumpster shall be $72.30 per container. 
(3)  Four-yard dumpster shall be $85.50 per container. 
Any additional collection shall be charged at the rate of $28.00 for a ninety-six-gallon bulk container, $72.30 for a three-yard dumpster, and $85.50 for a four-yard dumpster for each container for each pick-up. 
(e)  Each owner or occupant of each residence or business lying outside the corporation limits of the city receiving the automated garbage collection service shall be charged double the amount of the above rates. 
(f)  Each customer is provided one (1) bulk container, or a combination of bulk containers (as specified in section 6.206b) free of charge, and shall be replaced free of charge, when in the discretion of the Director of Public Works or his designee, the above container(s) is/(are) no longer serviceable. In cases of abuse or neglect, the customer will be charged a replacement fee which will be equal to the city's cost of the container. In the discretion of the Director of Public Works or his designee, the replacement fee may be waived in the case of theft, an accident or vandalism following a police report. 
(g)  Rates for brush clipping, leaf collection, drop-off and special yard-waste removal services. 
(1)  There shall be no charge for brush chipping, leaf collection or drop-off of material which complies with the terms of Section 32-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fredericksburg. 
(2)  Charges for brush chipping, leaf collection or drop-off of material which is placed for collection and non-compliant with the terms of Section 32-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Fredericksburg shall be $100.00 for each dump truck size[d] load of part thereof. 
(3)  Charges for special plant and tree pick-up service shall be based on a cost of $50.00 per man-hour or part thereof charged in 30-minute increments, and the City may require a deposit or prepayment of the same. 
(Code 1992, app. A, § 14.100; Ord. No. 6-017, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 8-065, § 14.100, 7-20-1998; Ord. No. 15-011, § 14.100(a)(1)—(3), 10-3-2005; Ord. No. 22-001, 1-16-2012; Ord. No. 24-020, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 25-025, 9-21-2015)

ARTICLE 16.000. - WATER AND SEWER RATES AND FEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 23-015, adopted Sept. 16, 2013, amended Art. 16.000 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. 16.000, pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for a detailed history of derivation. 
 
Sec. 16.100. - Charge for water and/or sewer connections and reconnections. 
(a)  Connection fees for properties intended for residential use, or which are otherwise installed by the City for residential use properties, utilizing a three-fourths inch meter are $1,500.00 for a maximum of 40 feet. Additional feet will be $37.50 per foot. 
(b)  Connection fees for properties intended for residential use, or which are otherwise installed by the City for residential use properties, utilizing a one inch meter are $1,550.00 for a maximum of 40 feet. Additional feet will be $38.75 per foot. 
(c)  Connection fees for properties intended for residential use, or which are otherwise installed by the City for residential use properties, utilizing a two-inch meter are $1,750.00 for a maximum of 40 feet. Additional feet will be $43.75 per foot. 
(d)  Connection fees for properties utilizing a four-inch sewer connection, typically for residential use properties, are $1,025.00 for a maximum of 40 feet. Additional feet will be $25.60 per foot. 
(e)  In addition to connection fees, a per meter charge of $30.00 shall be made for connections and reconnections to the City water system made during posted City business hours, and $50.00 at all other times including holidays. Such connection fee shall be payable at the time of application for service, or prior to reconnection as applicable. 
(f)  The rates provided for in this Section shall become effective on July 15, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013; Ord. No. 25-010, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 16.200 - Deposit for Water and Sewer Service. 
The deposit for water and sewer service is a combined deposit and is applicable whether the customer applies for one or both services. 
A deposit of a sum of money equal to two average monthly bills, and in no instance less than $75.00, shall be deposited with the City by each customer for each meter/service, at the time of making application for connection to the City's distribution system, with the express understanding that said deposit shall be held by the City as security for the payment of amounts owing or to become owing for water and sewer or other utility service furnished by the City to the customer. The City shall have the right to increase the amount of deposit if the customer's bills for any two consecutive monthly billing periods of normal operation actually prove to exceed the amount of the original deposit by more than 125 percent. For the purposes hereof, two average monthly bills shall mean the City's estimate of a similar class service with average usage for the type of property applied for. 
(Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013)

* This category shall include Manufactured Home Parks wherein one or more common meter(s) serves the entire development. The amount of the bill shall be determined as follows: The total number of gallons used for all meters divided by the total number of homes in the development each month shall be used to calculate the usage and this shall be added to the number of minimum fees times the said number of homes. Example for 20 homes with 200,000 gallons of usage: results in 10,000 gallons attributable to each home at $2.45 per thousand up to 6,000 ($14.70) and $3.92 for 6,001 to 10,000 ($15.68) or $30.38 per home plus the $11.60 minimum times 20 units, or $232.00 for a total bill of $839.60. The rates for Manufactured Home Parks in this category are effective November 1, 2019.

ARTICLE 18.000. - FEES FOR SANITARY LANDFILL 
(Effective October 1, 2014) 
Each individual, corporation or other entity, or member of a partnership using the public dumping grounds belonging to the City shall be assessed and shall pay to the attendant at such public dumping grounds, for the privilege of dumping or depositing garbage or other material at the said public dumping grounds, the following charges or fees for each load which shall be applied alternatively as applicable: 
(a) Minimum fee 	$10.00 
	
(b) Per ton 	$55.00 
	
(c) Appliances with compressors 	$30.00 each 
	
(d) No large animals (calf or larger) shall be accepted 	
	
(e) Oil filters and batteries 	$1.00 each 
	
(f) Passenger tires (20 inches or less) 	$2.00 each 
	
(g) Tires (greater than 20 inches) 	In accordance with the fee scheduleposted at the landfill 
	
(h) Paint 	$1.00 per gallon can 
	
(i) No hazardous waste shall be accepted 	
	
(j) Grass and leaves (not branches or brush) 	No charge 
	
(k) Purchase of compost from landfill 	$20.00 per pickup load 
	
(l) Metal, appliances without compressors 	No charge 
	
(m) No vacuum trucks allowed without first obtaining permit from the City of Fredericksburg 	
	
 
(Code 1992, app. A, art. 18.000; Ord. No. 6-018, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 15-011, art. 18.000(b), (e)—(m), 10-3-2005; Ord. No. 22-001, 1-16-2012; Ord. No. 24-020, 9-2-2014)  
ARTICLE 19.000. - ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER RATES AND FEES 
 
Sec. 19.108. - Charge for electric connections and reconnections. 
A per meter charge of $30.00 shall be made for connections or reconnections to the City electric system made during posted business hours, and $50.00 at all other times including holidays. Such connection fee shall be payable at the time of application for service. 
(Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 23-015, adopted Sept. 16, 2013, amended § 19.108 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 19.108 pertained to connections and reconnections, and derived from Ord. No. 8-053, § 19.108, adopted November, 1997.  
Sec. 19.200. - Proposed electric line extension policy. 
GENERAL: 
All service routes shall be determined by City 
If different service route chosen by customer, customer will pay 100% of extra costs 
All work shall be done by City crews or City contractor 
All materials shall be supplied by City 
COMMERCIAL: 
Customer pays all costs 
RESIDENTIAL: 
0 - 200 amp service = $300.00 Installation Fee 
201 - 320 amp service = $600.00 Installation Fee 
> 320 amp service = Same as Commercial 
Fees include up to 250 ft. of primary extension 
UPGRADES OF SERVICE (LARGER SERVICE NOT DIFFERENT TYPE OF SERVICE): 
City pays all costs 
Change of ownership does not qualify as upgrade of service 
SUBDIVISIONS 
Developer pays all costs except for

TEMPORARY SERVICE: 
Customer pays all costs 
CUSTOMER REQUESTED WORK: 
Customer pays all costs 
UNDERGROUND 
Customer pays all costs  
Sec. 19.300. - Deposit for electric service. 
A deposit of a sum of money equal to two average monthly bills, and in no instance less than $125.00, shall be deposited with the City by each customer for each meter/service, at the time of making application for connection to the City's distribution system, with the express understanding that said deposit shall be held by the City as security for the payment of amounts owing or to become owing for electric service furnished by the City to the customer. The City shall have the right to increase the amount of deposit if the customer's bills for any two consecutive monthly billing periods of normal operation exceed the amount of the original deposit by more than 125 percent. For the purposes hereof, two average monthly bills shall mean the City's estimate of a similar class service with average usage for the type of property applied for. 
(Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 23-015, adopted Sept. 16, 2013, amended § 19.300 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 19.300 pertained to deposit for electrical service, and derived from Code 1992, app. A, § 19.300.

ARTICLE 21.000. - DRAINAGE UTILITY FEES 
(a)  The following drainage utility fees are hereby established and shall be collected pursuant to Sec. 47-273 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  The owner or occupant of any residential lot or tract within the drainage utility service area, that receives any type of utility service (electricity, water and/or sewer) from the City of Fredericksburg, shall be assessed a monthly drainage utility fee as follows, based on the Main Building Area upon the lot or tract: 
Residential Tier 	Main Building Area 
(sq. ft.) 	Monthly Fee 
1 	= 1,000 	$3.00 
2 	>1,000 but =1,300 	$4.00 
3 	>1,300 but =1,600 	$5.00 
4 	>1,600 but =2,000 	$6.00 
5 	>2,000 but =3,000 	$7.00 
6 	>3,000 	$9.00 
 
(c)  The owner or occupant of any non-residential lot or tract within the drainage utility service area, that receives any type of utility service (electricity, water and/or sewer) from the City of Fredericksburg, shall be assessed a monthly drainage utility fee as follows, based on the Total Impervious Area of the lot or tract: 
Non- 
Residential Tier 	Total Impervious Area (sq. ft.) 	Monthly Fee 
1 	=1,800 	$3.00 
2 	>1,800 but =2,800 	$5.00 
3 	>2,800 but =5,500 	$9.00 
4 	>5,500 but =12,000 	$18.00 
5 	>12,000 but =50,000 	$50.00 
6 	>50,000 	$200.00 
 
(d)  Property owned by a religious organization that is exempt from taxation pursuant to V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.20 shall be exempt from any monthly drainage utility fee. 
(e)  Property used for cemetery purposes, if the cemetery is closed to new interments and does not accept new burials, shall be exempt from any monthly drainage utility fee. 
(f)  The Director of Public Works and Utilities, or his/her designee, shall be responsible for determining the Main Building Area and/or Total Impervious Area for all lots or tracts, based on reliable data, including but not limited to, Gillespie County Appraisal District data, GIS database data, aerial photography, information received by the City through the building permit process, or other reliable means for determining Main Building Area and/or Total Impervious Area. The Director of Public Works and Utilities, or his/her designee, may request additional information from a property owner or occupant as reasonably necessary to determine each property's impact to the drainage utility of the City. 
(Code 1992, app. A, art. 21.000; Ord. No. 7-006, 8-14-1995; Ord. No. 8-037, 10-21-1996; Ord. No. 23-015, 9-16-2013; Ord. No. 2019-01, § 2, 1-21-2019)  
ARTICLE 22.000. - [EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES] 
 
Sec. 22.101. - Fees and Charges for Emergency Medical Services. 
The fees and charges to the person or entity utilizing or receiving services rendered by the City's Emergency Medical Services ("EMS") are as follows: 
(A)  Basic Life Support, Non-Emergency (BLSN). Transportation by emergency medical technicians when no drugs or oxygen is administered: $800.00. 
(B)  Basic Life Support Emergency (BLSE). Transportation by emergency medical technicians when no drugs are administered. Oxygen may be administered: $850.00. 
(C)  Advanced Life Support Emergency (ALS-1). Transportation by paramedics when no drugs are administered. Oxygen may be administered and monitors may be used and an IV solution may be started: $950.00. 
(D)  Advanced Life Support Emergency, Major Trauma (ALS-2). Transportation by paramedics when at least one invasive procedure is administered (examples: defibrillation or cardiac pacing) and when at least one drug other than an IV solution is administered: $1,200.00. 
(E)  Aid only. City EMS is dispatched to a patient, but provides no patient transportation: 
1-5 calls dispatched to provide services to the same person within any 12-month period: no charge. 
6-10 calls dispatched to provide services to the same person within any 12-month period: $90.00 per EMS response. 
11-20 calls dispatched to provide services to the same person within any 12-month period: $180.00 per EMS response. 
21 or more calls dispatched to provide services to the same person within any 12-month period: $250.00 per EMS response. 
(F)  Mileage. $18.50 per loaded mile. This transportation charge shall be in addition to any other charges or fees set forth in this Section 22.101. 
(G)  Dedicated Standby. City EMS provides staffed ambulance for on premises standby at a private or for-profit special event. $100.00 per hour. This charge shall be in addition to any other charges or fees set forth in this Section 22.101. 
(H)  A Medical Records Fee in the amount of $45.00 shall be collected in advance of the issuance of any medical records. 
(I)  Medications and Supplies. Drugs administered by EMS to patients and disposable medical supplies utilized by EMS in treatment of patients shall be charged at the "list price" included in a catalog, price list, schedule, or other form that is regularly maintained by the manufacturer or vendor, and states prices at which sales are currently available, or were last made available to the City. This charge shall be in addition to any other charges or fees set forth in this Section 22.101. 
(J)  The Fire Chief, or his or her designee, shall determine which of the above rate categories apply to the services rendered by the City's Emergency Medical Services. The Fire Chief, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized to make any judgments with regard to per procedure cost in the application of the above rates, and his or her decision is conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 12-025, art. 22.000, 12-16-2002; Ord. No. 16-004, art. 22.00, § 22.101, 3-20-2006; Ord. No. 17-011, art. 22.00, § 22.101, 5-7-2007; Ord. No. 2018-32, § 1, 9-17-2018)  
ARTICLE 23.000. - [MUNICIPAL COURT TECHNOLOGY FUND] 
 
Sec. 23.100. - Establishment of Municipal Court Technology Fund. 
A.  There is hereby created and established a Municipal Court Technology Fund, hereinafter known as the Fund, pursuant to Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
B.  The Fund may be maintained in an interest bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(Ord. No. 17-010, art. 23.000, § 23.100, 4-2-2007; Ord. No. 21-010, 9-6-2011) 
Editor's note— Ord. No.21-010, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 22.100—22.102. These provisions have been included as an amendment to §§ 23.100—23.102, in which similar provisions are already codified.  
Sec. 23.101. - Establishment of Amount of the Fee and Assessment and Collection. 
A.  The fee shall be the maximum permitted by Texas State Law from time to time, and if not provided by Texas State Law then shall be in the amount of $4.00. 
B.  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the Defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense, or for violation of any City Ordinance, whether or not considered a misdemeanor, in the Municipal Court as a cost of court. A Defendant is considered convicted if: 
(1)  judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
(2)  the person is placed on deferred disposition; or 
(3)  the court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
C.  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed after September 6, 2011. 
D.  The Clerk of the Court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the municipal treasurer or other official who discharges or performs the duties of the treasurer of the City of Fredericksburg, Texas, who shall deposit the fee into the Municipal Court Technology Fund. 
(Ord. No. 17-010, art. 23.000, § 23.101, 4-2-2007; Ord. No. 21-010, 9-6-2011) 
Note— See editor's note to § 23.100.  
Sec. 23.102. - Designated Use of the Fund and Administration. 
The Fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of or to maintain technology enhancements for the Municipal Court of the City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
"Technology enhancements" shall include any and/or all items described in Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
The Fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Manager of the City of Fredericksburg, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 17-010, art. 23.000, § 23.102, 4-2-2007; Ord. No. 21-010, 9-6-2011) 
Note— See editor's note to § 23.100.  
Sec. 23.103. - Automatic termination. 
The collection of the court technology fund under this ordinance shall automatically terminate at such time as the City has collected the sum of $18,500.00. The Chief Financial Officer of the City shall certify to the Municipal Court Clerk the termination of the collection hereunder, and shall also notify the City Secretary who shall add such certification to the original of this ordinance in the ordinance records of the City. 
(Ord. No. 17-010, art. 23.000, § 23.103, 4-2-2007)

Any guest accompanying an Active Member will be entitled to pay Guest Rates for Residents of Gillespie County (set forth in subsection (a) above). Current Members will be allowed to book tee times TEN days in advance. 
(i)  LADY BIRD PLAYERS CLUB CARD. 
The General Manager for the Lady Bird Johnson Municipal Golf Course shall have the authority to make available for sale, and to change the sales price of, an annual "Players Club" Card. Holders of said Card will receive a rate to be shown lower than the published rate, but never at or below the Guest Rates for Residents of Gillespie County. The sales price of said Card on March 4, 2019 is $59.00. All cards are valid for the calendar year.

Small bucket - $ 5.00 
Large bucket - $ 7.00

The General Manager for the Lady Bird Johnson Municipal Golf Course shall have the authority to deviate from the rates set forth above in setting rates for tournaments or for special group rates. Additionally, the General Manager may temporarily decrease the rates described in subsections (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), and (g) to provide for specials at such times as he or she determines would encourage additional play. 
The rates set out above will be effective March 4, 2019, except as specifically set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 22-027, 9-17-2012; Ord. No. 23-018, 9-16-2013; Ord. No. 24-023, 11-17-2014; Ord. No. 26-012, 10-17-2016; Ord. No. 28-004, § 1, 4-16-2018; Ord. No. 2019-09, § 1, 3-4-2019)  
Sec. 24.200. - Fees for use of Lady Bird Johnson park pool and town pool. 
(a)  Daily admission per person is $2.00. 
(b)  Season pass per person is $50.00. 
(c)  Season pass per family not exceeding four persons is $125.00. 
(d)  Season pass for a family exceeding four persons is $125.00 plus $20.00 for each additional person. 
(e)  Swim lessons per session (approximately two weeks) is $30.00 per person. 
(f)  Group use fees shall be as follows: 
(i)  Town Pool during normal business hours for no more than 25 persons, including non-swimmers, for a maximum rental period of two hours: $35.00. 
(ii)  Lady Bird Park Pool during normal business hours for no more than 25 persons, including non-swimmers, for a maximum rental period of two hours: $50.00. 
(iii)  Town Pool outside of normal business hours, for a maximum number of 100 people and a rental period of two hours: 
$140.00 for 1 to 25 people, including non-swimmers. 
$170.00 for 26 to 50 people, including non-swimmers. 
$195.00 for 51 to 75 people, including non-swimmers. 
$250.00 for 76 to 100 people, including non-swimmers. 
(iv)  Lady Bird Johnson Park Leisure Pool and Baby Pool outside of normal business hours, for a maximum number of 100 people and a rental period of two hours: 
$140.00 for 1 to 25 people, including non-swimmers. 
$170.00 for 26 to 50 people, including non-swimmers. 
$195.00 for 51 to 75 people, including non-swimmers. 
$250.00 for 76 to 100 people, including non-swimmers. 
(v)  Lady Bird Johnson Park Pool—entire facility outside of normal business hours, for a maximum number of 125 people and a rental period of two hours: 
$190.00 for 1 to 25 people, including non-swimmers. 
$215.00 for 26 to 50 people, including non-swimmers. 
$275.00 for 51 to 75 people, including non-swimmers. 
$300.00 for 76 to 100 people, including non-swimmers. 
$340.00 for 101 to 125 people, including non-swimmers. 
(vi)  Additional conditions: 
All guests entering the facility as part of a group rental will be counted, without regard to a guest's actual length of stay or actual use of the pool. Any guests that exceed the number of guests in the reservation, which requires seven day advance notice, will not be admitted. 
Groups over 25 people may not reserve either pool facility during business hours, and must reserve the pool facilities for use at times outside of business hours. 
Groups that reserve the pool facility during business hours will have exclusive use of designated tables and/or areas, but the guests will not have exclusive use of the pools. Guests of groups that reserve the pool facility during business hours will share the use of the pools with the general public. 
The rates set out above [in subsection 24.200(f)] will be effective May 7, 2018, except as otherwise specifically set forth above. 
(g)  The Director of Parks and Recreation may temporarily decrease the fees set forth in this Section, at such days and times as determined by said Director, to encourage additional use of Lady Bird Johnson Park Pool and Town Pool.

Sec. 24.700. - Vendor fees and deposit fees for City sponsored special events; Participant fees for City sponsored recreational classes, camps, events, and programs. 
(a)  The fees and deposits charged to a person or entity providing vendor services for City sponsored special events are as follows: 
Vendor Type (defined below) 	Deposit Range 	Fee Range 
Food 	$0—$50.00 	$25.00—$100.00 
Craft 	$0—$50.00 	$25.00—$100.00 
Commercial 	$0—$50.00 	$25.00—$100.00 
Novelty 	$0—$50.00 	$25.00—$100.00 
Fredericksburg Civic/Service Org. 	$0—$50.00 	$0.00 
 
Vendor fees and deposit amounts listed are per booth, per event. Fees and deposit amounts will be established by the Parks & Recreation Director, or his/her designee, prior to each event, depending on the history, size, and scope of said event. 
(b)  Participant fee for City sponsored recreational classes, camps, events, and programs - Fee Range $0.00—$50.00 - Each participant in a City sponsored recreational class, camp, event, or other program shall pay the participant fee established by the Department of Parks & Recreation. Participant fee amounts will be established by the Parks & Recreation Director, or his/her designee, prior to each class, camp, event, or other program, depending on the history, size, and scope of said class, camp, event, or other program. The participant fee may established per person, per the duration of the class, camp, event, or program (e.g. per week, or per session). 
(c)  Definitions. As used in this Section 24.700, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Food vendor. Person or entity selling or otherwise providing samples or giveaways of food or beverages of any type. 
(2)  Craft vendor. Person or entity selling handmade items and artwork that have a unique design or require skilled work. Examples of craft items include handmade woodwork, art, jewelry, quilts, and floral design. 
(3)  Commercial vendor. Person or entity selling or reselling commercial items, services, or kits, typically under a corporate contract or trademark. Examples of commercial items include: Scentsy, Tupperware, and Avon. 
(4)  Novelty vendor. Person or entity selling children's products or performing children's services. Examples of children's products or services include: face painting, balloon art, sand art, glow products, and children's toys. 
(5)  Fredericksburg Civic/Service Organization. Person or entity that plans to participate in a special event as a method to market their organization and provides a free activity, game, or amusement for children (no charge to participants, subject to approval). The civic/service organization must be a non-profit organization and shall provide verification of non-profit status. Exceptions to the non-profit status verification requirement may be granted if evidence is provided demonstrating that the organization has an established history of charitable work in the Fredericksburg area. 
(Ord. No. 28-017, § 1, 10-1-2018)

(Ord. No. 2019-26, § 3, 9-3-2019)

Sec. 25.101. - [Late fees and other fines; exemption.] 
A late fee of $50.00 per calendar month, or portion thereof, shall be imposed on all renewing applicants for all permit fee payments made after 10 days following the due date of the fee, and the new or renewed permit shall not be issued until all fees, late charges and any outstanding fines or reinspection fees are paid. There shall be no refund of fees or proration of permit fees. Individuals or organizations which do not regularly (i.e. more than four times per year) sponsor or provide food service or directly or indirectly operate, or permit the use of its facilities to do so, an institutional kitchen, are exempt from the payment of such fees. Provided, however, this exemption applies only to the initial permit fee with accompanying inspection, Any reinspection, required or requested, shall be paid for. (8-111(c)) 
(Ord. No. 23-017, 9-16-2013)  
Sec. 25.102. - [Reinspections.] 
The fee for all reinspections is $50.00, except the first reinspection by the health officer which is required as a follow-up due to failure of an inspection or which is otherwise required by state law which will be performed at no charge. All reinspections requested by Food Establishment shall be paid for in advance. All other reinspections shall be paid for within 30 days following the reinspection. If not paid timely, a late fee of $25.00 per calendar month, or portion thereof, shall be imposed and the Food Establishment shall have its permit revoked under the method provided in section 8-114 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 23-017, 9-16-2013)  
Sec. 25.103. - [Issuance of copy of permit.] 
A fee of $5.00 is hereby imposed for the issuance of any copy of a permit which has been issued pursuant to this section. (Sec. 8-111 (e)) 
(Ord. No. 23-017, 9-16-2013)

ARTICLE 27.000. - EMERGENCY SERVICES COST RECOVERY FEES 
Cost Recovery Fees are based on a per hour cost, unless otherwise noted, and will be determined based upon on the descriptions below. The Director of Emergency Services or his or her designee shall determine the levels of service and total charge based upon the following. Not all services listed in each level must be provided for that level of billing to apply. Further, Cost Recovery Rates are average billing levels, and are typical for the incident responses listed. However, the Director of Emergency Services shall determine actual services provided and may adjust the Cost Recovery Rates based on the actual services provided. These rates become effective on October 24, 2014. 
(a)  Motor vehicle incidents 
Level 1 - $435.00 Stabilization 
Hazardous materials assessment and scene stabilization is provided. This will be the most common billing level. This applies in most cases when the fire department responds to an accident/incident. 
Level 2 - $495.00 Common materials or hazardous fluids 
Includes Level 1 services as well as clean up and material used (sorbents) for clean-up and disposal of common hazardous fluid such as gasoline and diesel or common materials such as cargo spills. Billing will be at this level if the City has to clean up, or becomes liable for the costs to clean up, any gasoline or other automotive fluids that are spilled as a result of the accident/incident. 
Level 3 - $605.00 Fire Suppression 
Scene safety, fire suppression, breathing air, rescue tools, hand tools, hose, tip use, foam, structure protection, and cleaning up of gasoline or other automotive fluids that are spilled as a result of the accident/incident are provided. 
Level 4 - $1,800.00 Rescue of person 
Includes Level 1 and 2 services as well as extrication (heavy rescue tools, ropes, airbags, cribbing etc.). The City will bill at this level if the fire department has to free/remove anyone from the vehicle(s) using any equipment. The City will not bill at this level if the patient is simply unconscious and fire department is able to open the door to access the patient. Billing at this level will occur only if equipment is deployed. 
Level 5 - $2,200.00 Multi engine, mutual aid helicopter per transport trip 
Includes Levels 1, 2, and 4 services as well as Air Care (multi-engine company response, mutual aid, helicopter). The City will bill at this level any time a helicopter is utilized to transport the patient(s). 
Level 6 - Extraordinary events 
Itemized Response: Billing for each incident which does not fit the above billing levels will be as an independent event with custom Cost Recovery Rates. Billing will use itemized rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable for each apparatus and personnel, plus products and equipment used. 
(b)  HAZARDOUS MATERIALS 
The following Cost Recovery Rates will apply for clean-up and disposal of un-common hazardous fluid or materials which require specialized services from outside sources. 
Level 1 - $700.00 Basic response 
Services are provided such as engine response, first responder assignment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, set-up and command. 
Level 2 - $2,500.00 Intermediate response 
Services provided which include engine response, first responder assignment, hazmat certified team, provision of appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, set-up and command, as well as any of: level A or B suit donning, breathing air, detection equipment and set-up and removal of decontamination area. 
Level 3 - $5,900.00 Advanced response for a 3 hour on-scene period 
Services provided which include engine response, first responder assignment, hazmat certified team, provision of appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command, level A or B suit donning, breathing air, detection equipment, robot deployment. Set-up and removal of decontamination area as well as any of: recovery and identification of material, disposal and environment clean up, including any disposal charges for material and contaminated equipment and mitigation material used at scene. Each additional hour will be billed at $300.00 per HAZMAT team. 
(c)  PIPELINE INCIDENTS/POWER LINE INCIDENTS 
This billing level includes, but is not limited to: oil, gas, sewer, septic and water pipelines. 
Level 1 - $400.00 Basic response 
Services provided include engine response, first responder assignment, appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command and inspection when damage or breakage is not found. 
Level 2 - $1,000.00 Intermediate response 
Services provided include engine response, first responder assignment, provision of appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command as well as any of: HAZMAT team, level A or B suit donning, breathing air, detection equipment, and the supervision and/or assistance in pipeline repair. 
Level 3 - Itemized response 
Billing for each incident which does not fit the above billing levels will be as an independent event with custom Cost Recovery Rates. Billing will use itemized rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable for each apparatus and personnel, plus products and equipment used. Services provided include engine response, first responder assignment, provision of appropriate equipment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command, HAZMAT team, Level A or B suit donning, breathing air and detection equipment, as well as any of: supervision and/or assistance with pipeline repair of intermediate to major pipeline damage, set-up and removal of decontamination center, detection, recovery and identification of material, disposal and environment clean up. 
(d)  POST FIRE INVESTIGATION 
Fire Investigation Team - $275.00 per hour. 
Services provided Include any of: 
•  Scene Safety 
•  Investigation 
•  Source Identification 
•  K-9/Arson Dog Unit 
•  Identification Equipment 
•  Mobile Detection Unit 
•  Fire Report 
The claim begins when the Fire Investigator responds to the incident and is billed for logged time only. 
(e)  FIRES 
Level 1 - Basic response - Assignment - $400.00 per hour, per fire engine/$500.00 per hour, per other rescue truck 
Services provided Include: 
•  Scene Safety 
•  Investigation during incident 
•  Fire / Hazard Control 
This will be the most common billing level applied every time the fire department responds to an incident. House fires and grass fires are examples of Basic response. 
Level 2 - Severe response; itemized billing 
Billing for each incident which does not fit the above billing level will be as an independent event with custom Cost Recovery Rates. Billing will use itemized rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable for each apparatus and the pay rates of personnel, plus products and equipment used. 
(f)  ILLEGAL FIRES 
Assignment - $400.00 per hour, per fire engine / $500.00 per hour, per other rescue truck 
When a fire is started by any person or persons contrary to permits, regulations or controls established by local or state rules, provisions or ordinances such person or persons will be liable for any fire department response at a cost for the actual expenses incurred by the fire department or other responding departments to respond and contain the fire. The actual expenses will include direct labor at the rates of pay for personnel, equipment costs and any other costs that can be reasonably allocated to the cost of the response. 
(g)  WATER RESCUE 
Level 1 - Basic Response - $400.00 per hour plus $50.00 per hour for each rescue person. 
Services provided include engine response, first responder assignment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, first responder set-up and command, scene safety and investigation (including possible patient contact, hazard control). 
This will be the most common billing level applied every time the fire department responds to an incident. 
Level 2 - Intermediate Response - $800.00 per hour plus $50.00 per hour for each rescue person. 
Services provided include Level 1 services as well as any of: clean up and material used (sorbents), minor hazardous clean up and disposal. The City will bill at this level if the fire department has to clean up small amounts of gasoline or other fluids that are spilled as a result of the incident. 
Level 3 - Advanced Response - $2,000.00 per hour plus $50.00 per hour per rescue person, plus $100.00 per hour per HAZMAT team member. 
Includes Level 1 and Level 2 services as well as any of: Drowning Accident Rescue Team activation, donning breathing apparatus, use of detection equipment, set up or removal of decontamination center, recovery and identification of material, disposal and environment clean up, including any disposal charges for material and contaminated equipment and mitigation material used at scene. 
Level 4 - Severe response; itemized billing. 
Billing for each incident which does not fit the above billing levels will be as an independent event with custom Cost Recovery Rates. Billing will use itemized rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable for each apparatus and the pay rates of personnel, plus products and equipment used. 
(h)  BACK COUNTRY, WATER OR SPECIAL RESCUE 
Itemized Response - $400.00 plus $50.00 per rescue person plus $400.00 per hour for each additional response vehicle more than one. 
(j)  MISCELLANEOUS - these rates apply in all cases not covered above 
Fire Engine billed at $400.00 per hour. 
Rescue Truck billed at $500.00 per hour. 
Miscellaneous equipment billed at $300.00. 
(Ord. No. 24-022, 10-20-2014)
